summary: The passage discusses a row between Paul Merson and Andros Townsend, a Tottenham midfielder. Merson initially criticized Townsend for writing in his Sky Sports column about the possibility of him being called up to the England team. Townsend scored an equalizer for England against Italy, and Merson admitted his mistake. However, Merson continued to have a negative opinion of Townsend, even after his performance against Burnley.

Chelsea have made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto. If he completes a move to Stamford Bridge this summer, Muto will join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan. The offer is not connected to the Â£200 million sponsorship deal they signed with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber in February. Muto would be the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea if he moves to west London.

A large-scale study has found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be fat as toddlers. The researchers said that antibiotics are used to make farm animals put on weight, and this may also be fattening our children. The study compared the weight and height of more than 12,000 healthy two year old with records on antibiotic prescription. By two years-old, one in five boys and one in ten girls was overweight or obese. And children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight. The study didn't prove that antibiotics were causing weight gain, but if they do, it may be because they kill of bugs in the gut that would normally feed on some of the food eaten. This frees up more food for the body.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, causing a commotion among the tourists. The incident was captured on camera by a tourist, who recorded the moment. The guard quickly scrambled to his feet and turned to march past the crowd, but his embarrassment was evident as he peered at the crowd from under his bearskin. The incident was unexpected and caused a stir among the tourists, who were watching the Changing of the Guard. The guard's fall was attributed to the metal protectors nailed to the soles of his boots.

The passage discusses the reimagining of the miniseries "Roots" for new audiences. The original series, which aired in 1977, had a massive audience of over 100 million viewers. A&E networks are remaking the miniseries, which will air in 2016. The producers plan to draw more from Alex Haley's classic novel and consult scholars in African and African-American history for added authenticity. The new version will be "original" and "contemporary" and will feature LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original series. The remade "Roots" will encounter a new generation of viewers who have witnessed Barack Obama making history as the nation's first African-American president and "12 Years a Slave" winning the Oscar for Best Picture.

The passage describes a former royal footman named Christopher Lawler who claims that palace aides tried to force him into an orgy in the 1970s. He was pinned to a chair and groped by a male member of staff on his first day working at Clarence House. The incident left him in tears and he left the job the same day. He finally decided to contact palace officials again last year after inquiries began into alleged cover-ups of child sex abuse by a VIP paedophile ring in the 1970s and 80s. The police are investigating claims made by Lawler.

The Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced they are expecting a child in a rap video they made set to the theme song from '90s television sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'. The video features Jesse and Melissa rapping as they drive in a car, with Melissa saying, "In Happy Valley, Oregon, livin' it wed, bought our first house and started to build our homestead." The video also includes a sonogram of their unborn child. The video was made so loved ones living far away could know about the baby.

The dress worn by Vivien Leigh when she played Scarlett O'Hara in the classic 1939 film Gone With the Wind has fetched $137,000 at auction. The dress, a jacket and full skirt ensemble, was worn in several key scenes in the 1939 movie, including when Scarlett O'Hara encounters Rhett Butler and when she gets attacked in the shanty town. The dress has suffered a little with age and has faded to light gray from original slate blue-gray color. The outfit has been part of the private collection of James Tumblin, formerly in charge of the hair and makeup department at Universal Studios. The dress was one of more than 150 items that were part of the private collection of James Tumblin, who began collecting onscreen costumes, props and behind-the-scenes artifacts from the film in the 1960s.

The passage describes a two-year-old boy who fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo while his parents were holding him. The boy was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived on the scene. He suffered minor bumps and bruises and was listed in stable condition at the hospital. The boy's leg was injured in the fall, but he was not attacked by the animals. The zoo has plans to press child endangering charges against the child's mother.

The speed camera in Wellington Road, Birmingham, has been turned around and is now pointing at the house. The camera has not been working for more than two years and has been decommissioned due to outdated technology. The owners of the house were not available for comment.

The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association has announced that Usain Bolt will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas next month. Bolt will compete at the relay championship on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team. Bolt confirmed his availability for the competition and expressed his excitement about running for Jamaica. The JAAA General Secretary, Garth Gayle, commented on Bolt's availability for the competition and expressed his expectation of some sprint magic on the track in the Bahamas on May 2nd and 3rd. The full Jamaican team list for the competition will be announced shortly.

The passage describes the dedication of Neymar and Dani Alves to Barcelona, as they supported the club's basketball side. They watched the Euro League contest between Barcelona and Real Madrid, which was won by Barcelona with a narrow 85-80 victory. Neymar also helped Brazil beat Chile 1-0 at the Emirates Stadium on Sunday. Neymar and his Barcelona team-mates will return to La Liga on Sunday to take on Celta Vigo.

The passage discusses the increasing number of migrants attempting to reach Italy from Africa and the Middle East. The Italian coast guard has rescued a total of 8,480 migrants over the past five days, with a further 400 feared missing. The Italian coast guard has not confirmed any specific incident involving a migrant boat capsizing, but there has been a recent upsurge in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy. The International Organization for Migration has reported that Italy has registered more than 10,000 migrants arriving in the first three months of 2015, and about 2,000 were rescued at sea during the first weekend of April in the Channel of Sicily. The passage also mentions that most migrants recorded this year come from countries in West Africa as well as Somalia and Syria, and that smugglers often use overcrowded vessels to transport migrants across the Mediterranean Sea.

The passage discusses the decision of Alexis Sanchez to join Arsenal instead of Liverpool. Wenger is pleased with Sanchez's decision and believes he is one of the best players in the world. The passage also mentions the interest of Liverpool in Sanchez and how it may have influenced the negotiations between Arsenal and Liverpool.

Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. He will ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes at the Lee Valley VeloPark. Wiggins, whose track pedigree includes three Olympic gold medals, is expected to set a mark which will last for some time. Wiggins will hope for a capacity 6,000 crowd to spur on his attempt, with tickets going on sale from April 19, while the event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports.

Serena Williams, the world number one tennis player, defeated Italian Sara Errani in the Fed Cup play-off on Sunday. The match was played on clay courts, which were difficult for both players due to the weather conditions. Williams, who won her 19th singles grand slam at the Australian Open, struggled to hit a thousand shots if necessary. She credited her success to her mindset of playing like she was on hard court instead of clay. Williams also congratulated Italy captain Corrado Barazzutti after competing in America's doubles defeat.

The passage discusses the interest of River Plate, a football club in Argentina, in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao. The club is open to the possibility of Falcao returning to the club after spending eight years with them before leaving for Porto in 2009. Falcao has struggled on loan at Manchester United this season, scoring just four goals in 18 appearances, and it remains to be seen whether United will exercise the option to keep him or if he will return to his parent club, Monaco. Falcao has been in good form for Colombia this week, scoring three goals in two games to equal Colombia's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals.

Ella Henderson has joined forces with dry shampoo brand Batiste. The 19-year-old singer has been announced as the official face of the brand's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. The partnership was fused together by the MILES agency. The international campaign launched with a TV advertising campaign, featuring the singer's latest single, Mirror Man.

The passage describes the aftermath of a fatal police shooting in Kenosha, Wisconsin. The incident involved a man named Aaron Siler, who was shot and killed by police officer Pablo Torres. The police association erected a billboard in his honor, but the family and friends of Siler are upset by the billboard and are calling for it to be taken down. The police association has stated that the billboard was not intended as a form of apology or support, but rather as a way to show appreciation for the community's support.

The passage describes the death of eight Iranian border guards in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan. The militants were killed by Iranian forces in the fighting, and the news agency cited Ali Asghar Mirshekari as saying that the militants crossed into the country from Pakistan. The Pakistani government condemned the attack as an act of terrorism, and the government has asked Iranian authorities to share any evidence they have.

The Japanese government's top military official, Defense Minister Gen Nakatani, revealed that the country's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) had never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object. He stated that the jets had, to date, never come across any UFOs from outer space.

The passage describes a passenger who was hospitalised after breaking a toilet while squatting on it in an airport terminal. The toilet collapsed and shattered on the floor, causing deep cuts on the passenger's leg and buttocks. The incident was reported to authorities, and the passenger was later hospitalised. The authorities believe the incident was an accident and have advised people not to use the toilets for standing on.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl found a hidden camera in her bathroom that police were able to trace back to the man. Rebbie was charged with aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation began when a 15-year-old girl found a hidden camera under the sink in a bathroom in her Limerick Township home in March, according to prosecutors. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, but had purchased the camera specifically so he could record the now-15-year-old victim while she undressed and showered.

The passage describes a series of photographs taken by Japanese photographer YÃ»ki Aoyama, which show a father and daughter posing together in front of various Japanese landmarks. The father is seen leaping into the air, while the daughter looks directly into the camera and smiles. The photographs are part of a book titled "Daughter and Salaryman," which roughly translates to "Daughter and Salaryman." The photographs are said to be part of a series of images that allow the father to express his fun side by being a "hero jumping the sky, enfold(ing) strong excitement and hope." The photographs are also described as being part of a book titled "Daughter and Salaryman," which roughly translates to "Daughter and Salaryman."

The passage discusses the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and the potential return of Kevin Pietersen to the England team. It also mentions the start of the county championship season and the potential return of Pietersen to the Test set-up.

The Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt has sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. The Brazilian defender was fired on Wednesday after a poor run, but was reinstated the next day after flamboyant owner Angelo Massone decided to give the coaching staff another chance. Ze Maria represented Brazil on 25 occasions during an international career spanning five years. The result left Ceahlaul 16th in the standings, six points adrift of safety. Ze Maria replaced Florin Marin in January to become Ceahlaul's third coach this season. He will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

The passage discusses Radamel Falcao's former Monaco team-mate Nabil Dirar's opinion on Falcao's failed loan move to Manchester United. Dirar believes that Falcao should be regretting his move to Manchester United, as he was not happy in France and may have been better off staying at Monaco. Dirar also mentions that Falcao has struggled to reach the heights he achieved before, suffering a serious knee injury. Additionally, Dirar notes that United will have to pay Â£46 million to make Falcao's transfer permanent, but they are unlikely to take up the option.

The passage describes a robbery that occurred in a Christchurch dairy. The robber was described as being very tall and wearing a distinctive cartoon mask. The robber demanded cash from the dairy owner's daughter and made off with the till and about $1500 in cash. The robber was reportedly wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt and an oversized mask. The robber remained at large and police are appealing to the public to help identify him.

The passage describes the arrest of Kaitlyn Granado, a teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, for having an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student. She was previously arrested in January for having an inappropriate relationship with another student. The passage also mentions that a school officer learned of a possible relationship between Granado and one of the boys last month and that a second boy was questioned about a possible relationship with her.

The video of a crocodile swimming through a public marina with a dead pet dog between its jaws has been viewed more than half a million times online. The video shows a large crocodile holding a black dog wearing a red collar in its mouth for hours. The crocodile was seen in the tourist hotspot of Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a local bike shop's owner's dog. The crocodile was described as being a common site in the Mexican beach resort, as the resort is built amidst the mangroves that the creatures have called home for centuries. The crocodile is regularly spotted on the resort's golf course.

Steve Bruce is confident that Hull City can avoid relegation this season. The team has six games remaining, including a tough fixture against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce believes that if the team remains positive, they can take a couple of results which will take them over the line. The team has struggled due to several long-term injuries to key players, including Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass.

The teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from the classroom after he let pupils change their exam answers, invalidating his whole school's SATs results. The exam session was finished, and the conduct panel heard about the incident. Guffick asked pupils at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury to make changes to their SATs exam answers. The panel ruled that no changes of any kind should be made to exam scripts outside test conditions. Guffick was later forced to give up his job at the school and had since admitted the allegations and accepted it amounted to unacceptable professional conduct. The Department for Education annulled the whole school's SAT's results after a probe by the local education authority. Guffick was banned from the classroom for at least two years.

The passage describes the relationship between Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard and his wife Miss Beqiri. They tied the knot in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius and have a son together. Lindegaard posted a link to Beqiri's Instagram account with the message "Day off with my sunshine @missebeqiri #cheshire #manchester". Despite struggling for minutes throughout his career in Manchester, Lindegaard has managed to win over fans with his marriage and his wife's modeling career.

The glowing blue letters that once lit the Bronx from above Yankee Stadium failed to find a buyer at an auction at Sotheby's on Wednesday. The 13 letters were expected to bring in anywhere from $300,000 to $600,000, but received no bids. The current owner of the signage is Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who purchased the 10-feet-tall letters for an undisclosed amount after the stadium saw its final game in 2008. The letters had beamed from atop Yankee Stadium near Grand Concourse in the Bronx since 1976, the year before Jackson joined the team. ESPN reports Jackson, who attended the auction, bought the letters 'on a lark.' Jackson joked that once he saw the size of the letters, some of which are also 10-feet-wide, he realized he might have gotten ahead of himself. He promised before the auction that if the letters were bought by a bidder in the United States, he would fly out to see the signage himself at the winner's home.

The passage discusses the situation involving Liverpool's players Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe, who were caught smoking shisha pipes while training. The manager Brendan Rodgers has reminded them of their professional responsibilities and urged them to learn from the incident. He has not disciplined either player for the incident, but he wants to draw a line under the matter. The manager also mentioned that Steven Gerrard is available for the FA Cup semi-final and that Rodgers' priority is steering Liverpool into their first FA Cup final of his reign.

The passage describes Mesut Ozil, a German footballer, returning to London after the international break. He posted a picture of himself relaxing with his dog, indicating that he is enjoying his home comforts. Ozil impressed on international duty as Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier on Sunday. He has been doing the business on the pitch since returning from injury, and is now set to start against Liverpool at the weekend. Ozil has been doing the business on the pitch since returning from injury, and is now set to start against Liverpool at the weekend.

The Barcelona club president, Josep Maria Bartomeu, has stated that the La Liga leaders have no plans to replace Luis Enrique and they are "very happy" with his performance. Bartomeu also refuted speculation that Enrique will be replaced in the summer. Luis Enrique, who took charge of the club last summer, has impressed during his tenure and has only six games left to win the title.

Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long-term contract with Liverpool, which will run until the summer of 2020. The club's vice-captain had 14 months remaining on his current contract and his advisors had been in talks with Liverpool since the beginning of this season. He is expected to put pen-to-paper on improved terms that are likely to be worth in the region of Â£100,000.

The passage discusses the situation of Filipe Luis, a full-back who signed a three-year contract with Chelsea last July. Despite Atletico Madrid considering bringing him back in the summer, he insists he wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his contract. Luis played in Brazil's friendly wins against France and Chile during the international break, but the focus now turns to the Premier League title run-in. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is refusing to let his league leaders rest on their laurels until the job is done.

Nathan Hughes, a Wasps No 8, was initially suspended for three matches after accidentally knocking out George North during a match. However, the ban was overturned on appeal, and Hughes was allowed to return to action immediately. The incident occurred during a match between Northampton and Wasps, where Hughes collided with North's head as he scored a try. North was taken off on a stretcher, and it was later revealed that he had suffered a concussion. Hughes was also suspended for three weeks following the incident on March 27.

The passage describes the stunning sunsets in Washington caused by wildfires in Siberia. The sunsets were the result of raging wildfires in southeastern Siberia, which were started by farmers burning grass in their fields. The wildfires quickly grew out of control due to strong winds and spread throughout the region. The fires have destroyed dozens of villages in the region. The lingering smoke from the widespread fires was picked up by atmospheric winds and carried to the Pacific Northwest, causing parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia to see the results of the smoke, wind, and solar light combination. The reason people are seeing an intense red sunset is a result of smoke particles filtering out the shorter wavelength colors from the sunlight like greens, blues, yellows, and purples, making colors like red and orange able to penetrate the air unfiltered.

The passage describes how a Missouri woman, Becky Schoenig, was shocked when her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway. However, she was even more shocked when she learned that the police had found her car after receiving a tip from a man who recognized the vehicle as hers. The car had been modified with new red rims and detailing, and Schoenig was surprised to see that the steering wheel had some orange accents. Despite the modifications, Schoenig took to Facebook and posted a photo of her and her new ride, expressing her gratitude to the car thieves for pimping out her vehicle. She also attached a photo of the car, which many thought was a joke. Schoenig is now getting the vehicle professionally cleaned to deal with the strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana.

Manchester City players will lose Â£500,000-a-man in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The Premier League title holders give star players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart and Yaya Toure incentivised contracts to make sure the club stay within financial fairplay requirements and they will miss out on a big payday if City fails to reach the group stages of Europe's top competition.

The passage describes a football match between Manchester United and Altrincham, which was played on a Saturday afternoon. The match was played at Moss Lane, which is a small stadium compared to Old Trafford. The match was played without any ticket prices, and the crowd was small. The match was played with a 3-4-3 formation, and the home team scored twice in the first half. The match was won by Manchester United, and they are two points behind Middlesbrough with a game in hand. The match was played on a windy field, and the weather was not ideal for the match. The passage describes the achievements of two goalkeepers, England's Joe Hart and Italy's Gianluigi Buffon. Joe Hart, who has represented his country for 50 times, has praised Buffon as a 'legend of the game'. Buffon has won 147 caps, which is a long way off his 50th cap. Joe Hart is also featured in the passage, stating that he wants to keep going and rack up more caps.

The Mexican restaurant chain Chipotle has decided to enter the food delivery market by partnering with the app Postmates. The company will offer delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities, but will charge a nine percent service fee for delivery fees. The app uses independent contractors who drive their own cars in a similar model to Uber taxis. Other fast-food chains, such as Starbucks, Taco Bell, and McDonald's, are also exploring delivery services.

The parents of the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, are calling for the death penalty to be removed from the case. They believe that the continued pursuit of the death penalty could bring years of appeals and prolong the pain of the victims' families. They also urge the Justice Department to bring the case to a close in exchange for the defendant spending the rest of his life in prison without any possibility of release and waiving all of his rights to appeal.

The passage describes a custom-built Boeing 747-8 that has been converted into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire. The jet is believed to have cost the owner Â£400 million and contains various amenities such as a large dining room, a lounge, and an onboard restaurant. The jet is designed to fit the owner's specifications and has a large bed in the master bedroom. The jet is also equipped with a conference room, a chill-out area, and a state room. The jet is described as being one of the most luxurious private planes ever built and is said to be far more glitzy than first-class on commercial flights.

The passage describes SpaceX's attempt to land a Falcon 9 rocket on a floating barge for the first time. The rocket landed on the barge but tipped over, and SpaceX plans to try again. The passage also discusses the Dragon spacecraft, which will carry over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the International Space Station.

The passage describes the first wedding to be held at an all-new chapel of love in Las Vegas, which is the Graceland Wedding Chapel. The chapel is located at the Westgate Hotel and is the first permanent exhibit of Elvis Presley's artifacts outside his iconic Memphis, Tennessee, home. The winning couple will be married in the chapel on April 23, 2015.

The passage discusses the performance of Liverpool FC during their recent matches, particularly their victory over Newcastle United. The key points include:

1. Liverpool's vice-captain, Jordan Henderson, believes that his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League if they continue to perform well.
2. Henderson and Liverpool goalkeeper Simon Mignolet have played 47 games each this season, which is the most for any player in the top five European leagues.
3. Liverpool has fallen behind Manchester City in the race for the Champions League, but Henderson believes they can still catch up.
4. Henderson and Mignolet have both played crucial roles in the team's recent victories, with Henderson scoring a goal in the 9th minute and Mignolet making a save in the 20th minute.
5. The team's performance has been mixed, with some poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal, but Henderson believes they can still make up ground and finish in the top four.
6. Raheem Sterling scored the opening goal for Liverpool, and Joe Allen capitalized on a defensive mistake to score his first Anfield goal.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home with a victory over Napoli in Serie A on Saturday. Miralem Pjanic scored a goal in the 25th minute after a quick counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis saved shots from Napoli in the second half. Second-place Roma moved four points ahead of city rivals Lazio, who play later on Saturday. Napoli's winless streak was extended to five matches, and Diego Maradona's former club remained fifth.

The passage describes an uninspired campaign by Doncaster Rovers in League One, which saw them firmly entrenched in mid-table mediocrity. The team's League One encounter against Fleetwood Town was a goalless draw, which left the media team with a bit of a problem when they were faced with sticking up the match highlights on the club's YouTube channel. They made it short and sweet, just 27 seconds in fact with 14 seconds of match action. The managers on the touchline during the game were also mentioned.

The passage describes a man who captures a blood parrot cichlid in a fish tank and gives it a massage. The fish becomes very still during the massage and returns to the man's hand several times. The man also feeds the fish frozen blood worms and notes that the fish becomes more sociable after he starts playing with it on a daily basis.

The passage discusses the character and behavior of Ben Stokes, an English cricketer. Stokes has a reputation for being fiery and aggressive, which has led to him being dismissed from the England team last year. However, he has since returned and is now back in the team. The passage also mentions that Stokes has a good character and that he needs careful management to ensure that he stays focused and productive on the field.

The passage describes the upcoming Euro 2016 qualifier between Wales and Belgium, which is expected to be a sell-out event with a capacity of 33,000 people. The match will take place at the Cardiff City Stadium on June 12th. The top two teams in Group B, Wales and Belgium, have 11 points each from five games, with Belgium leading the group due to a superior goal difference. Wales' 3-0 victory over Israel in Euro 2016 qualifying has raised expectations that they can claim one of the two automatic qualification spots and make it all the way to the 2016 finals in France. The Football Association of Wales has received orders for tickets due to the high demand for the match.

The England Under-17 team has been named for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The team is made up of talented young players from various Premier League clubs, including Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, as well as Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi. The squad will play against Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland in the tournament.

Manchester City are interested in signing Anderlecht teenager Evangelos Patoulidis, who is regarded as one of the best talents to emerge from Anderlecht's youth set-up. The Belgian starlet rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy when his family wanted him to continue his studies. City have held discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock in the hope of agreeing a compensation package. Manuel Pellegrini is looking to build for the future by snapping up hot property Evangelos Patoulidis.

The passage describes the arrest of a man in connection with the death of a transgender escort named Vanessa Santillan. She was found strangled and beaten to death in a Â£400,000 flat in Fulham, south west London. The man arrested has been bailed and is being questioned by police. The investigation is ongoing and the police are asking anyone who may have had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward.

The passage describes a woman named Dawn who suffered seven miscarriages and was upset after discovering that her friend, Jamie, had stolen money set aside for her baby's grave stone. Jamie, who is also her partner, was caught on camera confessing to taking the money but blaming it on his girlfriend, Carol. Dawn was devastated by the revelation and felt betrayed and horrible. She was comforted by her partner, Jamie, after the show.

The passage describes the release of 200 Yazidis, a minority group of Christians, who were killed, captured, and displaced by the Islamic State (IS) in northern Iraq last summer. The majority of the released Yazidis were women and children, while the rest were ill or elderly. The freed Yazidis were received by the Peshmerga force that defends northern Iraq's semi-autonomous Kurdish region, and they were sent to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. The reason for the release is not clear, but it was coordinated by Arab tribal leaders. The Sunni Islamist militant group, ISIS, has been responsible for the violence against the Yazidis, who have suffered persecution for centuries.

The passage describes Harry Kane's impressive season with Tottenham Hotspur and England, where he broke through into the first team and into Roy Hodgson's squad. He has been nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards, and the passage highlights his celebration of his goals and the animated effect created by Copa90 to showcase his best moments.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers is still the right man to lead Liverpool forward after a season with no trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. Rodgers' future at Anfield has been questioned after a third straight season without a trophy, but the former Liverpool defender backed the Reds manager. Liverpool are seven points behind fourth placed Manchester City with a game in hand and look set to miss out on Champions League qualification for next season. Carragher received a Beacon Award at a ceremony in London on Tuesday for his community work on Merseyside.

James Hayward, a four-year-old boy, was frisked by airport security and forced to hand over his toy gun after it was deemed a security risk. The security officers demanded that he hand it over, and they also performed a thorough patting down and inspection of the primary school child. The boy's father, Phil Hayward, criticized how staff reacted in the situation. The security checks were described as 'ludicrous' and 'over-zealous'. The boy was given a replacement toy gun after returning from the holiday to Lanzarote.

The passage describes a man named Rich who is looking for a girlfriend or wife. He is seeking someone who loves pets, has accommodation available, and is willing to offer a company car, phone, and laptop. He is also looking for someone who enjoys the outdoors and is also a princess when needed. Rich is athletic, has tattoos, and is a heavy drinker and smoker. He is also independent and loves sports, fishing, and camping. The advertisement includes a list of requirements in his potential partner and personal details about himself.

Greg Dyke, the Football Association chairman, has been backed by five former England managers in his bid to push through radical changes to the number of homegrown players in club squads. The proposals include increasing the minimum number of homegrown players from eight to 12 and changing the rules so that 'homegrown' means having trained in England for three years before the age of 18 rather than before 21. The FA chairman wants to increase the number of homegrown players at top-flight clubs, but is facing opposition from the Premier League. The managers warn that failure to do so risks England falling further behind the leading football nations and will only make it harder to end the long wait to win the World Cup. The rise of Harry Kane and other talented young players suggests that England can still produce top young talent.

The passage describes the recent addition to the Poldark series, Demelza Poldark, who has given birth to a baby girl. The story is set against the backdrop of the show's previous pregnancy storyline, which saw Elizabeth go into labor in the gap between two episodes. The Lancashire County Council has earmarked land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for development. The study found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are less likely to receive one. The study found no support for the "reticent female" theory, where women avoid asking for more money. The study found that men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The study also found that there was no evidence for the idea that women were reluctant to ask for a salary increase because they were more wary of upsetting their boss, or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. The study found that the size of the employer and the industry, whether the workers were a parent, and their qualifications had an impact on whether they asked for a pay rise. The study was based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey. The study found differences according to age, with women and men under 40 both asking for and receiving pay rises at the same rate. The study potentially has an upside, as young women today are negotiating their pay and conditions more successfully than older females, and perhaps that will continue as they become more senior.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported that it counseled more than 4,500 children in the past year, compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. The charity said online trolls caused misery and humiliation for thousands of children. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, said the figures should be a wake-up call. "Bullying can wreck young people's lives, especially now that the bullies don't stop at the school gates," she said. "Cyber-bullying can follow them home until it becomes a persecution they cannot escape. "It is imperative that adults, parents, and teachers intervene to protect them, because we have learned over the years from Childline callers that bullying does not stop on its own, left alone it gets worse. "Schools must take this problem seriously, and above all children must ask for help." The report is being released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, which is coordinated by the Anti-B

The passage discusses the move by the US to abstain from voting on a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction. The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee had indicated it would press ahead with a planned vote on authorizing new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, but the vote was postponed due to the request of the prime minister's office. Justice Minister Claire Sugden has confirmed that a motion will be put before the assembly for approval. The motion will bring Northern Ireland into line with England and Wales, where plans for automatic pardons were announced last month. Those proposals would see men convicted of now-abandoned sexual offences receive posthumous pardons. The law will also allow living men convicted of such offences to apply for a pardon. The motion in the assembly is expected to contain the same provisions and allow for pardons both posthumously as well as for living gay and bisexual men. The minister said she has secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offences. Ms Sugden said that arrangements would be brought in "as soon as possible to ensure that there is equal treatment for gay and bisexual men here as for their counterparts in England and Wales". The motion will now go forward for consideration by the assembly.

The PDP's decline has been reinforced by results from Saturday's elections for governors and state assemblies. The PDP won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The passage discusses the allegations made by a US-based environmental lobby group, Mighty, against two major agricultural commodity traders, Olam and Temasek. Mighty accuses Olam and Temasek of turning a blind eye to the use of slash-and-burn practices by small-scale farmers and rogue palm oil traders in Indonesia, which is blamed for causing haze. The passage discusses the potential changes to the planning system in Northern Ireland. The passage describes the case of a one-year-old cat named Teenie who was shot twice in the shoulder and once in its left back leg. The vet had to amputate the one-year-old cat's left back leg. The study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found that many pupils take their internet-connected devices to bed, and that the rapid growth of tablet computers in the classroom is one of the ways in which young people are immersed in technology at school and home. The exhibition Growing Up in the City at the Museum of Liverpool showcases 25 evocative photographs capturing the life of children over more than 100 years. The pictures provide a snapshot of childhood lost days and a thought-provoking social history of life in Liverpool through the decades. The exhibition is curated by Kay Jones, Curator of Urban Community History at the Museum of Liverpool. The 50-year-old actress, O'Donnell, fell ill at home and searched for symptoms online. She visited a cardiologist who inserted a stent into an artery that was 99% blocked. The passage describes the new role of Powys Council in delivering estate agent regulation services in place of the Office of Fair Trading (OFT). The passage discusses the issue of staffing shortages in the NHS, particularly in the area of junior doctors. The passage describes an accident involving a bus and a car on the Lower Bristol Road in Bath, which caused traffic disruptions and delays during rush hour. The passage discusses the impact of a tidal lagoon on salmon and sea trout populations in the North Wales region. The Woodland Trust is planting thousands of new trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley to commemorate the millions of people who died during World War I. The passage describes the injury suffered by Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner, during his second game for Worcestershire in 2016. The author also mentions that Apple had offered the two-factor verification system in the past, but it had not been implemented when device owners used the firm's back-up service.

The charity confirmed that all cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, had ingested a toxic substance. The passage describes the return of Grant Mitchell, a character from the soap opera EastEnders, to the show after a brief absence. The character was last seen in 2006 and was played by Ross Kemp. The passage describes the case of Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon, who stalked Alice Ruggles and attacked her last October. Dhillon had become obsessed with Ruggles and stalked her. The newly-designed form used to apply for a divorce in England and Wales asks for the name of the person your spouse has committed adultery with. Family lawyers say that, in most cases, involving a third party adds "conflict and complexity". The Ministry of Justice said there was "no obligation" to name people. But Georgina Hamblin, director at divorce lawyers, Vardags, said people are "unlikely to read the much smaller print or choose to ignore it". The passage discusses the importance of trees for timber production in Britain, particularly in Wales, where conifer forests have been a significant part of the timber industry for decades. The HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays in getting offenders to start their work and said too many were let off if they did not attend. The passage describes the life and career of Dr. James D. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur who turned his efforts to mapping the human genome into a competitive race. The passage discusses the results of a survey conducted by the England's School Food Trust, which found that four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they had not tried at home. Half of parents questioned said their children had asked for foods they had eaten at school to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while the least popular were aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach. The survey was conducted online between 26 February and 5th March among a panel of parents who had at least one child in school aged 4-17 years old.

The passage describes the career of Morata, a Spanish footballer who joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. He has scored three times for Spain in the Euro 2016 tournament and has scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italia titles. Morata has also played in back-to-back Champions League finals, appearing as a substitute in Real Madrid's 2014 win and scoring in Juventus' 3-1 defeat by Barcelona in 2015. The passage also mentions that Morata came through the ranks at Real Madrid and made his first team debut at 18, scoring 10 goals for the La Liga side.

The passage describes Wilson's career as a professional footballer, including his time at Forest, Celtic, Preston North End, and Notts County. It also mentions that he rejoined Forest in August 2013 after being released in May.

Tesco is looking to dispose of its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, which operates 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona. The deal involves transferring around 4,000 employees to the new business and loaning around Â£80m to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company focused on supermarket and restaurant businesses. If Yucaipa is successful and the business becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake.

The passage describes a man who initially experienced racial abuse but overcame it and is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. It also mentions a special guide on getting into martial arts.

The passage describes the retreat of glaciers in the French Alps over the past 40 years. The glaciers in the Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye, and Grande Rousse Arves massifs, as well as the famous Mont Blanc Massif, have lost significant areas of ice. The retreat is not uniform across the French Alps, with the greatest losses seen in the southern sectors. The northern region includes the biggest French glacier of all, La Mer de Glace, which has lost some 26% of its area over the last 40 years. Efforts to assess and monitor glacier health are ongoing across the Alpine region.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers to date and host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday knowing victory would all but secure their place. Iceland, ranked one place above the Scots at number 20 in the world, are also unbeaten after four wins from four, with the outcome of Friday's contest and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September likely to decide who tops the group. The best six of the eight group runners-up also qualify automatically, Scotland are in pole position to reach next summer's finals in the Netherlands without the need for a play-off.

The passage describes the arrest of Stuart Campbell, a former computer games reviewer, in the west of England. He was arrested following a complaint from a woman in south London who alleged harassment over a two-year period. Campbell was released on bail and accused the media of "innuendo" designed to encourage "speculations". He accused the blogger of being a vocal campaigner for Scottish independence and launching the Wings Over Scotland blog in 2011. Campbell has been bailed, pending further inquiries, to a date in mid-September.

The people for the ethical treatment of animals (PETA) wants the mascot of Skegness to be replaced with a modern animal-friendly version. The group has suggested a fish with the slogan Skegness - A Happy Plaice. The mayor of Skegness said all suggestions were welcome but said he did not think there would be much support for Jolly to be axed. The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned by the Great Northern Railway to encourage visitors to take the train on their seaside breaks to Skegness. The poster featured the slogan "Skegness is so bracing". It was commissioned in 1908 for 12 guineas and has become synonymous with the Lincolnshire resort. However, Dawn Carr, of PETA, said Jolly "evokes images of cruelty to animals". "Fish being tricked into impaling themselves in the mouth, animals being pulled out of the ocean in giant nets where they are so crushed together the pressure pushes their stomachs out through their mouths and their eyes pop out." "This is what the Jolly Fisherman represents," she said. She said PETA's suggestion would give the resort an opportunity to rebrand itself as a progressive holiday destination

The passage describes a rugby match between Scotland and Georgia. Scotland leads 38-11 at halftime, with Stuart Hogg scoring four tries and Greig Laidlaw converting two. Georgia scores two tries in the second half, but Scotland manages to hold onto the ball and score more points. The match ends with Scotland leading 42-11.

The passage describes the match between Widnes Vikings and Castleford Tigers, which ended in a 38-12 loss for the Vikings. The Vikings were led by tries from Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, but were unable to hold on to their lead as Castleford scored three tries in four minutes. The Vikings were also unable to stop Castleford's Solomona, Monaghan, Crooks, Webster, Flynn, McShane, Gale, Jewitt, Milner, Patrick, Moors, McMeeken, Massey, and Replacements Millington, Springer, Tickle, Cook. The Tigers won the match despite losing nine of their previous ten matches.

The passage describes the release of Fawzi al-Odah from the US facility in Cuba after a US review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat". He had been arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, and had challenged America's right to detain him in the US Supreme Court. He was released after the Guantanamo Periodic Review Board determined that continued law of war detention of Mr Odah did not remain necessary to protect against a continuing significant threat to the security of the United States. He now faces at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait. The total number of inmates at the US naval base has dropped to 148, with the release of five Taliban detainees in May when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl, who had been kept by the insurgents in Afghanistan.

The passage describes the events surrounding Anzac Day, a day commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. The service was held at Hyde Park Corner and Westminster Abbey, with the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia being sung. The first time Anzac Day was commemorated in the capital was when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service in 1916, a year after the Anzac landings at Gallipoli. The parade at the Cenotaph featured prayers read by schoolchildren and the national anthems of all three countries. The passage also mentions the eight-month campaign on the Gallipoli peninsula in Turkey, which was one of the bloodiest of the war and an attempt to force the Ottoman empire out of the war.

The passage describes the football career of Clarkson, a player who has played for Premiership Well and St Mirren. He has scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has featured mainly as a substitute so far this term. He is ready to play and has been training hard to prepare for his debut against Alloa on Saturday. He has also been capped twice for Scotland and has made almost 400 senior appearances at club level. St Mirren is eighth in the Championship and seven points clear of bottom side Alloa.

The passage describes the sale of a turkey firm to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. The new owners, however, were concerned about the pension scheme of the existing workers. However, Unite regional officer Steve Harley assured them that all current agreements would be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and its members have an alternative pension scheme which is unaffected by the takeover. The Boparan Private Office confirmed that the current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews would continue under the new ownership. Mr Harley met with representatives from Boparan at the Great Witchingham headquarters and said that the new owner wishes to restore Bernard Matthews to its former position as a highly profitable business. This would be achieved by greater investment in the business, cost savings, and utilizing the present spare capacity at Bernard Matthews to process chicken and not just turkeys.

The passage describes a scrutiny meeting of the council to discuss the problems surrounding the new vessel. Council leader Dave Stewart said that the crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July "in recognition of the problems" and to allow feedback. The council had ordered a review of the project by auditors. The ferry has broken down, run aground, been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to "training issues", and has caused damage to cars getting on and off. Shopkeeper Angie Booth, who owns Valu-4-U in East Cowes, said that whether she comes out of this and survives is not clear, as other businesses are also bearing the brunt of the loss of almost six months of trade. Transport councillor Ian Ward said that compensation is up for discussion. He added that he doesn't think it's a disaster, but it's a prototype, and there are bound to be teething problems. There were electrical problems which the company has rectified. Groundings were an issue with seamanship, which had been resolved.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights the risk of Britain losing control over its fishing waters and the potential for increased competition from EU countries. The passage also mentions the importance of maintaining market access for the UK fishing industry and the need for the UK to ensure that total allowable catches and quotas continue to be based on scientific advice.

Timothy Geaney, a registered teacher, admitted taking or permitting the images to be taken between April 2004 and February 2014. He was made the subject of a community payback order and put on the sex offenders register earlier this year. He has now been removed from his profession's register following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing. The nature of the offence meant Geaney had "condoned and participated in an industry that violates and abuses children". The panel found that Geaney had failed to uphold the standards expected of the profession. The offending behaviour had taken place over a lengthy period of time "demonstrating that there was a pattern of behaviour, as opposed to an isolated incident". Given the volume of images and the duration of the conduct, taken with the lack of evidence of remedial action, the panel was of the view that there was a strong likelihood of the offending behaviour recurring. The panel found him unfit to teach and removed him from the professional register.

The passage describes the aftermath of a fire at a waste disposal site in Duncan Street, which caused travel delays and reduced train services. The Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The fire service raised concerns to the EA about the impact a fire could have on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The EA revoked the environmental permit for the site operator, Asset and Land Group, and requires them to remove all the waste. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The Deputy Foreign Minister of Syria, Faisal al-Mekdad, stated that his country is doing its best to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons. However, Syria missed the deadline on Wednesday and a shipment of weapons came under attack twice on its way from Damascus to the port of Latakia. The US Secretary of State, John Kerry, condemned the government's use of barrel bombs in the city of Aleppo, and the Syrian government denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison.

England won the fourth Test against Pakistan by 217 runs at Old Trafford. England made 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared to set up their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. England's Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. England's captain Alastair Cook made 105 and 76 not out. England's coach Trevor Bayliss said that Root went away and did a bit of soul-searching and hard work, came back and did exactly what he said he was going to do. England's coach Trevor Bayliss said that Root went away and did a bit of soul-searching and hard work, came back and did exactly what he said he was going to do. Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, will call on pensioners and their friends and families to share their experiences of residential care. The evidence gathered will be used to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The commissioner's review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales will focus on physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. The review will also speak to care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. The chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, expressed disappointment that the commissioner did not include a provider expert on the main advisory panel.

The passage describes the appointment of former Dons midfielder Sheerin as player-manager at Arbroath, replacing Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. Arbroath was relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing bottom of League One. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser chose Sheerin after a comprehensive process, despite wishing to retain his services. Sheerin played for several Scottish clubs and also featured for Ãstersunds in Sweden before moving into coaching. He guided Arbroath to their first national trophy in their history by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011.

The passage discusses the appointment of Curtis as the new manager of Swansea City, replacing Bob Bradley. Curtis believes that the club has not been the same since Michael Laudrup left in 2014 and that the current squad is good enough to stay up. The passage also mentions the promotion of Swansea to the Premier League in 2011 and the establishment of a reputation as a well-run club with a team that played exciting, possession-based football.

The passage describes the life and career of Dr. James D. Watson, a biologist and entrepreneur who turned his efforts to mapping the human genome into a competitive race. He was vilified by the scientific community for his claims of a level of consistency with other scientists who have won the Nobel Prize in medicine. However, his efforts in the field of human genomics have undeniably helped speed up the entire process. Dr. Watson also turned his attention to another grand project: the creation of a synthetic life form. Scientists at the US-based J Craig Venter Institute have been busily working on the endeavor for more than a decade. They have now published details of the result, an organism called Synthia, in the prestigious journal Science.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in Europe are low quality and too short, and that the Department for Education is reforming apprenticeships to drive up standards. The report also notes that England has a patchwork vocational system with too many young people offered qualifications of little worth, and that the majority of apprenticeships are aimed at older workers. The report calls for apprenticeships to be radically expanded, with up to 300,000 new starts each year. The majority of these should be at level three at least for three years, with some four-year courses at level four - higher than A-levels.

The passage describes the British Paralympic cyclist, Storey, who won a 17th title in Nottwil, Switzerland. She is targeting further Paralympic success at the 2016 Games in Rio de Janeiro. Storey is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals. She has won 11 gold, eight silver and three bronze medals in both cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. She won four golds at the 2012 Games in London and has now won 21 world titles across both sports. Storey began her sporting career in the pool, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005.

The Bulls' financial troubles have been a major factor in their relegation from the Football League. They were reinstated as a Conference Premier club and Hayes & Yeading will stay in Conference South. Hereford United can have no complaints about the Conference's actions. The Conference had originally offered a payment deadline of Thursday, 5 June. The club's debt to their football creditors, including former boss Martin Foyle, members of the current squad, other club staff and clubs from whom the Bulls loaned players during the 2013-14 season, added up to Â£148,000. The deadline was extended three times, to Friday, 6 June, then again to Saturday, 7 June and for a third time until Thursday, 12 June. But it became clear on Tuesday that the Bulls, taken over last week by London businessman Tommy Agombar, would not make that deadline - and the Conference has now acted. The last team to be expelled from the Conference was Chester City in February 2010. They reformed as Chester FC two months later - and it is now they who have taken the Bulls' place, following a dramatic final day of the season when, almost simultaneously

The former Manchester City man, 30, won 61 caps for England after making his senior debut in 2009. He was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships but played just three minutes at Euro 2016. The decision to not play at Euro 2016 was made due to common sense. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, picking up 46 caps after making his first appearance in 2004.

Christopher Hogwood, a conductor and musicologist, passed away in Cambridge following an illness. His funeral will be private, and a memorial service will be held at a later date. He worked with many leading orchestras around the world and was considered one of the most influential exponents of the early-music movement. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973 and directed it across six continents for some 30 years. He made more than 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. He studied keyboard at Cambridge University with Rafael Puyana and Mary Potts and later with Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt. He was the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He was also a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University in the US.

The passage describes the story of a boy from Northern Ireland who is unable to attend mainstream schools due to his family's concerns about his mental health. The boy's mother had to take on a second job to support him, and the family had to make the difficult decision to remove him from mainstream schooling. They requested a place at a special school, but were told that all the special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full to capacity. The boy's mother is worried that this situation will happen to other families as the special needs school system is packed to capacity.

The Welsh Rugby Union has announced that they intend to take over the Newport Gwent Dragons rugby team, which is based at Rodney Parade. The takeover will be put to a vote by the club's shareholders in early May. The club has a lease on the ground and has the right to use it as a rugby venue if they remain in the Football League. The WRU has stated that they will not install an artificial surface at Rodney Parade, which is against Football League rules. The club is currently two points clear of the League Two relegation zone and can clinch survival if they win and rival Hartlepool lose. The club's chairman, Will Godfrey, has stated that losing the status of being in the Football League would be a "massive" blow to the fans and the city of Newport.

The passage describes the author's experiences during the civil war in Sierra Leone, including his training as a child soldier and his work with the Liberian Red Cross during the Ebola crisis. The author reflects on his experiences and the impact they had on him, and how they have shaped his perspective on life and the future.

The Wedgwood Museum has received a donation of about 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from the Art Fund. The collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund led the campaign, and the Wedgwood Museum inherited the pension bill of Waterford Wedgwood plc after the firm collapsed in 2009. The museum also went into administration in 2011, and in 2011 a high court judge ruled its collection could be sold to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund.

The passage describes the potential deal between Dan Groves and Wright, a club director, for Wright to buy 20% of the club. The club is currently in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points behind a play-off spot. Billericay has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who said he was comfortable investing Â£10,000 a week. The club signed former England international Paul Konchesky at the start of March.

The Seasiders scored their first goal after 12 minutes, while Blackpool equalised from a corner. Colchester failed to take the lead, and Blackpool should have won the game, but they were unable to do so. Jim McAlister was shown a straight red card for a bad tackle on Sean Murray in injury time.

The disused Fawley power station chimney will be the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard. Developers Fawley Waterside plan to build a merchant city development around the chimney, which will include a petal-shaped glass structure, a marina, housing, and restaurants. The project is expected to be completed in 2018 and will feature an application for outline planning permission due later this year. The power station was commissioned in 1971 and was capable of powering one million homes.

The passage describes the performance of the British cycling team at the Hong Kong championships. The team's sole rider in the men's keirin, Joe Truman, was out-classed in his semi-final, while the women's team pursuit team finished fifth in the heats but failed to make the bronze-medal ride. The team's sole rider in the women's team pursuit, Elinor Barker, came into the quartet of Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd, and Ellie Dickinson but was unable to compete for a medal. The team's sole rider in the men's team pursuit, Adrian Teklinski of Poland, won gold, while Lucass Liss of Germany got silver. The team's sole rider in the women's team pursuit, Katy Marchant, was eliminated from the women's sprint in the first round.

The passage describes the return of Grant Mitchell, a character from the soap opera EastEnders, to the show after a brief absence. The character was last seen in 2006 and was played by Ross Kemp. The story involves Barbara, the character's mother, who returns to the show after a surprise return in 2010. Barbara's character is killed off in the show, but Grant Mitchell returns to reunite with his mother and brother. The episode is emotional and will be screened in the spring.

The passage discusses the performance of two football teams, Tottenham Hotspur and Chelsea, during a match at Anfield. Tottenham Hotspur scored twice in the first 138 seconds of the match, while Chelsea could extend their lead at the top of the Premier League table if they beat Burnley on Sunday. The passage also mentions Tottenham Hotspur's poor away form, with only one win in their past 17 matches against top-six teams. Danny Murphy, a former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder, criticized Tottenham Hotspur's performance, stating that they were "all over the place" against Burnley.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in the 2015 Nigerian general elections, defeating the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). The PDP lost the presidential poll for the first time in its history, and its decline has been reinforced by results from Saturday's elections for governors and state assemblies. The PDP lost control of Adamawa, one of three states badly hit by militant Islamist group Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the party managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC has made historic gains, relegating the once-powerful PDP to a regional party. The PDP failed to get a national spread of votes, doing well only in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. Most states in the north went to the APC, along with Nigeria's commercial hub, Lagos, in the south-west. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states. This will be of huge concern to President-elect Muhammadu Buhari, as militant groups could disrupt oil production and starve the federal government of much-needed oil revenue. The Hebridean Celtic Festival will offer an augmented reality experience for visitors to use an app to trigger online information from items such as signs and posters on the site. The festival will take place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July. The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean are among this year's acts. The festival director said that the augmented reality experience will allow people around the world to interact with the festival and capture a flavor of its atmosphere at any time. The augmented reality experience will be updated in the run-up to the festival and during the event, allowing people to instantly access information and interviews, buy tickets, and get a taste of the unique festival wherever they are.

The passage discusses the closure of two Birmingham academies, Park View and Nansen Primary, due to inadequate ratings by Ofsted. The trust managing the schools, Park View Educational Trust, may be removed from running the schools. The head teacher of one of the Trojan Horse schools, who was targeted by parents, said she tried to address the concerns but ultimately quit her job. The report into Park View School stated that the school's work to keep students safe, including from extremism, was inadequate. The report also highlighted issues with external speakers and guest speakers. The passage describes the death of Vincent Barker, who died in July 2012, five months after undergoing a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution has accused eye specialist Honey Rose of gross negligence manslaughter, stating that her conduct was so far below the expected standard that it was "criminal". The trial continues.

The passage describes the case of Clive Weatherhogg, who set up meetings with a woman through an adult website and filmed her having sex with a man. He was found guilty of coercing the woman to engage in sexual activity and intercourse with the man between 10 September, 2013 and 17 September the following year. He was also convicted of intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to look at sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner on 25 December, 2014. The judge sentenced Weatherhogg to a term of imprisonment, which was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh.

Ireland made 165-5 in Greater Noida, but were defeated by Afghanistan by 16 runs. Samiullah Shenwari and Mohammad Shahzad scored 56 and 47 respectively, while Afghanistan's Samiullah Shenwari and Mohammad Shahzad added 51 runs. Amir Hamza took 2-23, while Boyd Rankin was ruled out due to a back problem.

The Spanish champions, Barcelona, paid Â£48.6m for Brazilian striker Neymar, 22, in the summer. The fee included an initial fee, signing-on fee, wages during his five-year deal, agents fees, and a tax payment. The club added that it remains convinced that the original tax payment was in line with its fiscal obligations. However, there is a possibility of a divergent interpretation of the exact amount of tax responsibility arising from the signing. The club has made a complimentary tax declaration of a total of 13,550,830.56 euros, although it remains to be seen whether the case will be dropped after the payment.

The bodies of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were discovered on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. Metropolitan Police officers flew out to work with Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects. The UK detectives will now compile a report and update the families of Hannah and David. The police team wish to thank the Thai authorities for facilitating the visit. Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both migrant workers from Myanmar, are alleged to have confessed to the killings. Thai police have denied subsequent reports that the pair, both aged 21, have since withdrawn their confessions. The two suspects are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape and robbery, and could face the death penalty if found guilty. The UK Foreign Office last month summoned the Thai charge d'affaires to express concerns about the police investigation.

Scotland is in a strong position to qualify for the 2019 FIFA Women's World Cup after winning all five of their qualifiers. However, they face Iceland in a crucial match on Friday. The Scots are hoping to avoid the same fate as they did in the 2013 and 2015 UEFA Women's Championship, where they lost in the semi-finals. Iceland is ranked one place above Scotland and has won four of their last five matches. The match will be played at Falkirk Stadium and the outcome could determine who qualifies for the finals.

The passage discusses the use of third-party software to steal intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud. The author suggests that Apple should implement a security measure to prevent this type of attack. However, the security facility remains an opt-in choice. The author also suggests that Apple should make it the default option. The passage also mentions that hackers have been using pirated copies of Elcomsoft's "forensic" software to access iCloud content without needing to be in possession of a suspect's iPhone or iPad.

The passage describes the campaign expenses of the UK Independence Party (UKIP), the Conservative Party, the Liberal Democrats, and the Green Party during the 2017 UK general election. UKIP spent Â£2,956,737, while the Conservatives spent Â£2,980,815. The Liberal Democrats spent Â£1,580,575 and lost all but one of their MEPs. The Greens spent Â£534,249 on their campaign. The six highest-spending parties spent a total of Â£9,347,087 on campaigning.

The passage describes the transfer of two football players from their clubs to their National League rivals. The first player is Anderson, a centre-back who has cancelled his Barrow contract by mutual consent and will join their National League rivals. The second player is Keating, a striker who was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, and his move to the Gulls is subject to international clearance. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, named Many Clouds, collapsed after narrowly beating Thistlecrack to win the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The horse was treated by veterinary staff before being pronounced dead. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed that the horse suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. The horse had no significant underlying health issues, and episodes such as this are rare. The horse had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, but had never collapsed before. Many Clouds had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime".

Tricia Marwick shed tears after veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil bid farewell to the parliament. Ms Marwick and Mr Salmond are among those standing down as MSPs ahead of the election on 5 May. Mr Salmond used his valedictory address to repeat a belief he expressed in his very first speech in the parliament that Scotland was "not divided, but diverse". He said both the country and parliament were on a journey, and added that there was in fact a broad consensus on the need for this parliament to assume greater responsibility for the governance of Scotland. He welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill, but again insisted the bill did not fulfil the pledges which he said had been made by unionist politicians in the last days of the referendum campaign. Mr Salmond joked that he wished everyone standing in the forthcoming election good luck, "albeit with varying degrees of enthusiasm".

The 1991 animated version of the film Beauty and Beast will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. The film stars Dame Angela Lansbury as Mrs Potts, the housekeeper magically transformed into a teapot, and Kevin Kline as Maurice, the father of the 'Beauty' character Belle. Emma Watson will play Belle, and Dan Stevens will play the Beast. Luke Evans will co-star as Gaston, and Josh Gad will voice LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the movie, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will reveal its intentions at a meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST. Ninety-six football fans were fatally injured in the 1989 stadium disaster. The Hillsborough disaster was ruled unlawful by new inquests last year. Files of evidence relating to 23 suspects were referred to the CPS to decide whether charges should be brought. The families of the victims have been invited to a private meeting in Warrington, where they will be informed of the decisions by Sue Hemming, head of the special crime and counter-terrorism division at the CPS. The families are determined to never give up and want accountability.

The passage describes the Chelmsford Prison in Essex, where numerous incidents of packages being hurled over the wall have occurred. One former inmate has stated that the prison is notorious for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice has stated that staff work extremely hard to stop contraband from getting into prisons, but more must be done to address the issue. The passage also mentions that packages have been thrown over the wall four times in two weeks, and that the prison wants residents to come to an evening to discuss what to do if anything does get thrown over. The passage also notes that drones have been used to fly contraband goods straight up to prison windows, but there is no evidence of drones coming into the Chelmsford site. Finally, the passage states that laws have been introduced which mean people who smuggle packages over prison walls could be jailed for up to two years.

The passage discusses the role of the BRCA1 gene in the development of breast and ovarian cancer. It states that women carrying the BRCA1 gene can reduce their risk of death once they have been diagnosed with breast cancer by having their ovaries removed. The couple, Derek Lowe and Tina Lowe, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina. The passage describes the case of a baby boy who was found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury's bag floating on a village pond 27 years after his body was discovered.
