The passage describes several tornadoes that occurred in Kansas on Wednesday night, with one tornado reported near Goddard, 15 miles west of Wichita. Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight bout on Saturday in New Jersey. The passage describes a light general aviation aircraft that lands without its landing gear deployed on a runway in Fort Pierce, Florida. The passage discusses Manchester City's midfielder Yaya Toure, who has been criticized for his performances this season. The passage describes an argument between two Brisbane neighbours over noise levels, resulting in one man's death and the other being charged with manslaughter. The passage describes a freelance photographer named Atif Saeed, who captured an image of a hungry lion from just a few feet away. The New York City Police Department has released an image of a tattoo found on the body of a woman who died in Brooklyn last month. The New Zealand couple built a home on the back of an old flatbed truck. They purchased a 1986 Hino flatbed and undertook a year and a half of labor of love to build a solar-powered two-bedroom, wood and steel home. The result is a cozy, all-wooden home that allows them to live almost self-sufficiently in Nelson, New Zealand. The truck became the foundation of the home, and the couple made do with what they had to build the home. They started with a steel frame and gradually built the home over the course of a year and a half. The home is powered mostly by solar panels, and the couple even plans to build another one like one day.

The passage discusses the impact of sharing iPads in class on early literacy tests. It states that children who share iPads do significantly better in these tests compared to those who do not. The research conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in classes over an academic year scored around 30 points higher than their peers who used the device on their own and non-ipad users. The study suggests that the collaborative learning around the technology made the difference, not just the collaboration in and of itself. The findings have implications for how schools use technology, particularly in earlier grades, to make the technology most effective.

The passage describes a piglet that was born without its back legs and learned to walk on its front legs. A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone's car during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana. The passage describes a husband who battered and shot his wife multiple times while she was dancing. He confessed that he did this because he was jealous of other men looking at her. The passage describes the personal battle of a journalist and author named Sarah Wilson with mental illness. She experienced anxiety that led her to believe her life was not worth living. An Oregon woman named Elena Curtin was charged with second-degree assault after she hit her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. She beat her with a crowbar and the ex-girlfriend refused to leave. The ex-girlfriend was jealous and bitter that the boyfriend was in a relationship with her. The boyfriend struggled with heroin in the past and had a five-year-old child with the ex-girlfriend. They have since reconciled and Curtin is now living with her parents. If she had gone to trial and been convicted, she would have received a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

The passage describes a pit bull named Gemma who is being fed broccoli as part of a trick to make her eat vegetables. Gemma pulls a look of disgust when she chomps on the broccoli and spits it out on the floor. The passage also mentions that Gemma enjoys sleeping and hanging out with her human family.

The HSBC website was directed to a pornographic page after a link on the website was accidentally redirected to the page. The pornographic page was created after the awards were scrapped in 2011 and the organizers allowed it to be registered on the HSBC website. The bank removed the link from its main website after realizing its mistake.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus provided instructions to firefighters during a 911 call when his family's home caught fire on Sunday morning. He and his nine-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom after the fire broke out on the first floor of their home in Clinton. Marcus called 911 shortly before 7 am after he smelled smoke and told the dispatcher that his older brother, mother, and step-father were also in the home. He told the dispatcher that his sister was screaming, "We're going to die," during the call. The firefighters were able to rescue Marcus and his sister by going through the home and breaking a window. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.

The passage describes the stunning sight of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically Jervis Bay in New South Wales. The algae was captured by photographer Andy Hutchinson, who described it as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton omitting light. A similar display was shown in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, where an oceanography expert told Daily Mail Australia there was no need to be concerned about the algae. However, experts have long-believed that the risk of cancer recurrence for certain women is a lot less than for others, and that for some, chemotherapy may not be necessary. A large-scale study has found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be fat as toddlers. The researchers said that antibiotics are used to make farm animals put on weight, and this may also be fattening our children. The study compared the weight and height of more than 12,000 healthy two year old with records on antibiotic prescription. By two years-old, one in five boys and one in ten girls was overweight or obese. And children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight. The study didn't prove that antibiotics were causing weight gain, but if they do, it may be because they kill of bugs in the gut that would normally feed on some of the food eaten. This frees up more food for the body.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, causing a commotion among the tourists. The incident was captured on camera by a tourist, who recorded the moment. The guard quickly scrambled to his feet and turned to march past the crowd, but his embarrassment was evident as he peered at the crowd from under his bearskin. The incident was unexpected and caused a stir among the tourists, who were watching the Changing of the Guard. The guard's fall was attributed to the metal protectors nailed to the soles of his boots.

The dress worn by Vivien Leigh when she played Scarlett O'Hara in the classic 1939 film Gone With the Wind has fetched $137,000 at auction. The dress, a jacket and full skirt ensemble, was worn in several key scenes in the 1939 movie, including when Scarlett O'Hara encounters Rhett Butler and when she gets attacked in the shanty town. The dress has suffered a little with age and has faded to light gray from original slate blue-gray color. The outfit has been part of the private collection of James Tumblin, formerly in charge of the hair and makeup department at Universal Studios. The dress was one of more than 150 items that were part of the private collection of James Tumblin, who began collecting onscreen costumes, props and behind-the-scenes artifacts from the film in the 1960s.

The incident occurred on EnQuests's Thistle platform, off Shetland, last December. Rigging supervisor Steve Innes, from Sunderland, told the BBC he and fellow Wood Group contractors discovered they had been exposed to alpha radiation. EnQuest said "additional precautionary steps" had since been taken. Wood Group said it was committed to employee safety. Mr Innes - who said he has struggled to find more work since raising concerns - said the workers now faced cancer fears, and blood tests were ongoing. He said EnQuest had failed in its duty of care. Mr Innes claimed they were told there was a problem two thirds of the way through the trip. He claimed a health and safety manager told them a reading had been taken the night before and all the work was stopped. He said: "We had all been working on it without the proper PPE (personal protective equipment), because they had assumed it was clear. "At first we were all in shock. The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a statue of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari from Art of the Past for $650,000 in 2007. The John Moores Painting Prize is an annual art award in Britain. It was established in 1957 and has previously awarded prizes to David Hockney and Peter Doig. The 1991 winner of the prize was 76-year-old artist Simpson, who received the Â£25,000 prize for his painting Squint (19). Simpson was one of the shortlisted artists in 1991 and has also made the prize longlist on three other occasions. He won a Grammy Award for his work on Quincy Jones's album "Back on the Block" and was nominated for two Oscars for his work with Jones on the soundtrack for "The Color Purple".

The Lancashire County Council has earmarked land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for development. The study found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are less likely to receive one. The study found no support for the "reticent female" theory, where women avoid asking for more money. The study found that men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The study also found that there was no evidence for the idea that women were reluctant to ask for a salary increase because they were more wary of upsetting their boss, or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. The study found that the size of the employer and the industry, whether the workers were a parent, and their qualifications had an impact on whether they asked for a pay rise. The study was based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey. The study found differences according to age, with women and men under 40 both asking for and receiving pay rises at the same rate. The study potentially has an upside, as young women today are negotiating their pay and conditions more successfully than older females, and perhaps that will continue as they become more senior.

The Oxford City Council has been searching for a suitable new burial site for many years, but has not found one that is suitable. The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, King George winner Thistlecrack, collapsed after narrowly beating the Trevor Hemmings-owned gelding Many Clouds to win the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The NSPCC's Childline service reported that it counseled more than 4,500 children in the past year, compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. The total number of children suffering online abuse is thought to be far higher. Some children as young as seven told Childline how they were tormented, abused, and scared to go to school. The charity said online trolls caused misery and humiliation for thousands of children. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, said the figures should be a wake-up call. "Bullying can wreck young people's lives, especially now that the bullies don't stop at the school gates," she said. "Cyber-bullying can follow them home until it becomes a persecution they cannot escape. "It is imperative that adults, parents, and teachers intervene to protect them, because we have learned over the years from Childline callers that bullying does not stop on its own, left alone it gets worse. "Schools must take this problem seriously, and above all children must ask for help." The report is being released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, which is coordinated by the Anti-B

The passage discusses the move by the US to abstain from voting on a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction. The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee had indicated it would press ahead with a planned vote on authorizing new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, but the vote was postponed due to the request of the prime minister's office. Justice Minister Claire Sugden has confirmed that a motion will be put before the assembly for approval. The motion will bring Northern Ireland into line with England and Wales, where plans for automatic pardons were announced last month. Those proposals would see men convicted of now-abandoned sexual offences receive posthumous pardons. The law will also allow living men convicted of such offences to apply for a pardon. The motion in the assembly is expected to contain the same provisions and allow for pardons both posthumously as well as for living gay and bisexual men. The minister said she has secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offences. Ms Sugden said that arrangements would be brought in "as soon as possible to ensure that there is equal treatment for gay and bisexual men here as for their counterparts in England and Wales". The motion will now go forward for consideration by the assembly.

The passage discusses the allegations made by a US-based environmental lobby group, Mighty, against two major agricultural commodity traders, Olam and Temasek. It mentions that Daisy is a clone of a sheep called Dolly, who was the first cloned mammal born in 1996. The passage also discusses the potential risks associated with cloning, such as the possibility of transferring "age-memory" from the adult animal to the cloned animal. The study of the cloned sheep is ongoing, and the results could have significant implications for the future of cloning.

The passage describes the performance of various horses in recent races, including trainer John Gosden's 4-7 favourite, Tasleet, who won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas. The passage also mentions the concerns of trainer John Gosden about his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and the upcoming Epsom Oaks.

The currency, the pound, initially slipped against the dollar and euro, but recovered in mid-afternoon trading before falling again. The "volatility index", a measure of investors' uncertainty, has hit levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign argued that the pound simply retreated to March levels. The Leave campaign argued that the pound simply retreated to March levels. The pound was down 0.2% against the dollar at $1.4226. Investors have been spooked by data showing the chances of a Remain vote have fallen, although markets have also been rattled by global economic worries. The Leave campaign argued that the pound simply retreated to March levels. The pound was down 0

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. The team faced a tough challenge against Barrow, who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games with the victory. Despite losing three games in a row, Cowley remains positive about the team's performance and their ability to overcome the challenges ahead.

The passage discusses the potential changes to the planning system in Northern Ireland. It mentions that the responsibility for planning decisions will shift from the Planning Service to the councils, which will be able to accept or reject developments in their own areas. This move is seen as a positive step towards democratising the planning system, as it gives local councils an opportunity to develop their own community and development plans. However, some politicians may not have the necessary skills to handle the new responsibilities, and there is concern about the potential for discrimination in the allocation of public housing. The Friends of the Earth group is concerned about the potential for close relationships between developers and political parties, and the need for good transparency in the planning process.

The passage describes the case of a one-year-old cat named Teenie who was shot twice in the shoulder and once in its left back leg. The vet had to amputate the one-year-old cat's left back leg. The Scottish government held a consultation on licensing air weapons last year, but a majority of responders opposed the plan. The cat's owner, Sarah Nisbett, said that the gun used in the shooting must have some power because the pellet actually went through her back leg. The Scottish SPCA is investigating the incident and is urging anyone with information about the incident to contact them.

The passage describes the signing of Benteke, a Belgian international, by Liverpool Football Club. He joins the club after scoring 49 goals in 101 games for Villa. Benteke joined Liverpool on a long-term contract after triggering a release clause in his contract. The club struggled for goals last season, but manager Brendan Rodgers has added Benteke to revive the Reds' attack. Benteke has previously missed the 2014 World Cup with an Achilles tendon injury but returned to action last October and scored 15 times to help Villa stay in the Premier League and reach the FA Cup final.

The passage discusses the use of tablet devices in schools and the impact they have on students' learning. The study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found that many pupils take their internet-connected devices to bed, and that the rapid growth of tablet computers in the classroom is one of the ways in which young people are immersed in technology at school and home. The study found examples of much more intensive use, such as an individual tablet device for every pupil in 9% of schools. The underlying trend is for an increasing number of tablet computers in schools, and the number of tablet computers is expected to rise from about 430,000 to almost 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. However, the study does not make a definitive connection between tablet computers and improved results. Head teachers reported a positive impact, and there is evidence that they help to motivate pupils who might otherwise be disengaged. Dr. Barbie Clarke, who conducted the study, says that the role of technology is going to grow in schools, and that the type of device might change, but it is not going to go away. She believes that the use of technology in school also reflects the reality of how pupils

The exhibition Growing Up in the City at the Museum of Liverpool showcases 25 evocative photographs capturing the life of children over more than 100 years. The pictures provide a snapshot of childhood lost days and a thought-provoking social history of life in Liverpool through the decades. The exhibition is curated by Kay Jones, Curator of Urban Community History at the Museum of Liverpool. The oldest image dates back to 1887 and shows children at a fancy dress ball hosted by the Mayor and Mayoress of Bootle. The exhibition is open until 25 September.

The passage describes the signing of two football players, Anderson and Keating, by their respective clubs. Anderson has cancelled his Barrow contract and joined their National League rivals, while Keating was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, and his move to Gulls is subject to international clearance. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

The passage discusses the new Bolivian law that allows 12-year-olds to be contracted to work for others, but requires parental authorization. The law sets harsher punishment for violence against children, including a sentence of 30 years in jail for child homicide. The law was approved by Congress earlier this month and signed into law by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in the absence of President Evo Morales, who was traveling to Brazil. The law aims to help eradicate extreme poverty in Bolivia, and the International Labour Organization says children under the age of 15 should not be allowed to work. However, the law allows a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries.

The 50-year-old actress, O'Donnell, fell ill at home and searched for symptoms online. She visited a cardiologist who inserted a stent into an artery that was 99% blocked. She experienced sudden nausea and aches before taking a few aspirin. She also had a heart attack last week and became nauseous and feverish after helping a woman who was struggling to get out of her car in her Nyack village home. She is now hosting a daily talk and gameshow called The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network.

The passage describes a stabbing incident that occurred in Belvedere Way, Kenton, on Saturday evening. The boy identified as Che Labastide-Wellington, from Harrow, was at the party and was stabbed later in an alleyway. The boy was pronounced dead about an hour later. Another boy was also stabbed and taken to a north London hospital for treatment. The police believe that Che was not involved in an early altercation with a group of youths denied entry to the party. However, he appeared to have been targeted later. The police have arrested a man on suspicion of murder and taken him to a west London police station for questioning. Two boys have also been arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed until mid-December.

The passage discusses the reorganisation of cancer diagnosis in Denmark, particularly focusing on the problem of patients with vague or difficult-to-diagnose symptoms. The changes introduced include fast-track diagnosis and treatment routes for patients with specific cancers, diagnosis centers for patients with symptoms that GPs cannot diagnose, and yes-no centers for patients with minor symptoms. The passage also highlights the positive outcomes of these changes, such as improved survival rates and better organization of patient diagnoses within existing resources.

The passage describes the new role of Powys Council in delivering estate agent regulation services in place of the Office of Fair Trading (OFT). The new role will issue warnings and bans against agents acting dishonestly or breaching estate agent laws. The OFT will disband, and Powys will receive Â£170,000 a year to carry out the work. People complaining about estate agents will still contact their local authority trading standards department, who will prosecute offenders if necessary. However, Powys will refer cases to the new role if they believe parts of the Estate Agents Act have been breached.

The passage discusses the issue of staffing shortages in the NHS, particularly in the area of junior doctors. The Nuffield Trust has recommended that the NHS employ more nurses to fill in for doctors when they are unavailable. However, unions have warned against using this as a quick fix, as it may not address the underlying issues of the NHS workforce. The report highlights the changing nature of care, with more emphasis on long-term conditions such as diabetes and heart disease. The NHS Employers have asked the Nuffield Trust to look at ways to reshape the workforce to improve patient care and provide more rewarding roles for staff. However, Dr Mark Porter, the British Medical Association's leader, has expressed concern that increasing the skills of the workforce should not be done at the expense of good quality training for doctors or doctors themselves. Christina McAnea, the Unison head of health, has also raised concerns about the lack of funding for training courses in the NHS.

The passage describes an accident involving a bus and a car on the Lower Bristol Road in Bath, which caused traffic disruptions and delays during rush hour. The incident was investigated, and the A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT. The local live news reported that parts of the services had resumed a normal schedule, but it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal. The managing director of Avon and Somerset Police thanked the public for their support and understanding and expressed his gratitude to the staff for their efforts.

The passage discusses the impact of a tidal lagoon on salmon and sea trout populations in the North Wales region. NRW estimates that the lagoon would result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying each year as they migrate to and from local rivers. Tidal Lagoon Power disputes these figures and claims that NRW refused to share its methodology for calculating them. The Welsh Government is considering the findings of a six-month review of the viability of the scheme, which is yet to be published. NRW disagrees with TLP's criticism and says it has received a vast amount of evidence on the subject from the applicant and held detailed discussions with the developer for a year-and-a-half.

The passage discusses the establishment of a new agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland. The body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), which will provide strategic leadership and direction for the marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. The move was announced by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster, who stated that the establishment of the new body will provide a significant and exciting opportunity for the Northern Ireland agri-food industry to work together for the benefit of the entire sector. The Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement and expressed concern about the implications for other organizations, including her own department.

The Woodland Trust is planting thousands of new trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley to commemorate the millions of people who died during World War I. The project aims to plant "millions" of native UK trees and is one of the trust's most ambitious planting programs. The conservation charity is inviting local people and visitors to the Faughan Valley to get involved and make a mark on history through the simple act of tree planting. The trees will stand for generations to come and will be a living, growing tribute to the people from Ireland who played a part in the war.

The Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award was given to Hilary for her book "Someone Else's Skin". The radio times TV editor Alison Graham described the book as "an emotionally exhausting and powerful story". Sara Paretsky, who created detective VI Warshawski, received an outstanding contribution honor. The accolades were handed out at the start of the North Yorkshire town's annual crime writing festival. Ann Cleeves, this year's festival programming chair, said the crime novel of the year shortlist had been "really strong" this year. The panel had felt Hilary's winning book was "so finely written and tightly written". The other books on the shortlist were: Sara Paretsky was chosen for the outstanding contribution to crime fiction award after her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago. Actress Kathleen Turner played VI Warshawski in a 1991 movie based on the Deadlock novel and in a BBC Radio 4 adaptation. VI Warshawski was "a real game changer", Cleeves said. "This was a woman who didn't just solve crimes but was like an action hero in a sense." Paretsky "really

The passage describes the injury suffered by Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner, during his second game for Worcestershire in 2016. He broke his finger and was disappointed to pick up the injury in his very first T20 game. He has rejoined the team after the ICC Trophy in England and is looking forward to making up for lost time and making an impact with bat and ball. The team has also signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

The passage describes the death of Barry Pring, a wealthy man, who was killed by a speeding car while trying to hail a taxi on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev in 2008. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was returning to a restaurant for a missing glove when the accident occurred. The coroner at Exeter County Hall, Dr Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing. The case demonstrated the difficulty in investigating a case of a death abroad, and the family of Barry Pring believes he was killed in a staged hit and run accident. The case is still active but not actively pursued.

Sophie Fearns, the mother of Charlie Fearns, a 10-year-old boy with cancer, is seeking more T-cell therapy for her son at Seattle Children's Hospital. The treatment failed in the UK, and the family is now relying on a anonymous donor to cover the costs. The family is grateful for the donation and is hoping to start the treatment as soon as possible.

The passage discusses the recent hack of iCloud, where third-party software was used to steal intimate photos of celebrities. The author suggests that Apple should implement a two-factor authentication system to prevent such attacks. The system requires users to enter a four-digit code that is either texted to a trusted mobile phone number or sent via Apple's Find My iPhone app. If the code is not entered, the user is blocked from making purchases on the iTunes, iBooks, or App Store. The author also mentions that Apple had offered the two-factor verification system in the past, but it had not been implemented when device owners used the firm's back-up service.

The passage describes Dan Groves' statement about a potential deal between Wright and Billericay FC. The deal would see Wright buy 20% of the club, and he would become a club director. Billericay is currently in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points behind a play-off spot. Wright has played non-league football for various clubs, including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. Billericay has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who said he was comfortable investing Â£10,000 a week. The club signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, at the start of March.

Mr Ashley was asked to give evidence about the treatment of his workers by the BBC. He has until 21 March to respond after a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright. The letter states that Mr Ashley had invited the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee to a meeting at the company's base in Shirebrook. The committee will keep an eye on the treatment of low-paid workers and the enforcement of the national minimum wage. If Mr Ashley fails to respond, the committee may take further action, including seeking the support of the House of Commons.

The passage discusses a report written by Russian opposition politician Ilya Yashin titled "Putin. War." The report claims that Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive to securing all major victories claimed by pro-Russian rebels in eastern Ukraine. The report also presents evidence of volunteer soldiers who admit that it was Russian generals, not separatists, who directed the main battles in eastern Ukraine. The report is based on facts that have already appeared in Russian and foreign media since Crimea was annexed in March 2014 and conflict broke out in eastern Ukraine. The report is being published to extend the initial print run of only 2,000 copies. The report is being published despite the fear of Russian families for their soldiers' safety.

The passage describes the death of Craig Nelson, who was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire. He was 34 years old and died as a result of head injuries. The man and woman who were arrested in connection with his death were 41 and 23 years old respectively. They were both from Sheffield and remain in custody.

The passage discusses the relationship between the UK government and the Welsh government regarding the Article 50 letter. The UK government has stated that they want to develop a negotiating framework for the whole of the UK, but the Welsh government has expressed disappointment that they were not consulted on the letter. The Welsh Secretary, Alun Cairns, has criticized the UK government for treating the devolved administrations with a lack of respect. The article also mentions that the UK government has stated that they want to see powers devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, but the identity of the powers is still unclear.

The passage describes two cars being damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin is "appalled" by mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page reported that police were carrying out duties when attacked. The page also appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

The passage describes the ouster of Mr. Charney, who founded the company, due to employee complaints and allegations of misuse of company funds. The court filing states that the board does not expect him to return to the firm. Mr. Charney's lawyer said that many of the statements made were false. The court filing documents evidence of illicit emails written to female employees by the former chief executive, as well as racially derogatory taunts. The company's papers state that Mr. Charney "repeatedly engaged in conduct that violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy." The court adds that the risk to the company and its shareholders would be too great if Mr. Charney were hired as CEO, executive, or employee.

The passage describes the upcoming game between GB and Greece, which will be played in London at the Copper Box. The game will be the only home game for GB before they compete at FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which starts in September. The game will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. Three members of the Greek team will be missing at the Copper Box, giving GB a chance of revenge. The game will be exciting for the players, as it will be their first time playing at the Copper Box.

The passage describes the launch of the iPhone in 2007 and its impact on the way people use smartphones. The author describes the excitement of the launch and the challenges of getting a glimpse of the new device before it went on sale. The author also discusses the impact of the iPhone on the way people think about photography and other activities they can do on the move. The author concludes by expressing gratitude for witnessing a moment in history.

The charity confirmed that all cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, had ingested a toxic substance. The most recent case involved a seven-month-old cat named Meereen, which died on Monday. An RSPCA spokesperson said it was unclear whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate. Other cats in the area have also died in the last seven days, while another cat died two weeks ago. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, said the cat came home on Friday evening and "seemed to be shivering a little". She has been "devastated" since the cat died. The charity is appealing for everyone in the area to ensure pesticides and chemicals were stored safely.

The passage discusses the current situation in Greece, where the Syriza government is poised to agree and implement yet more austerity and liberalization measures, despite the fact that Greece's resorts are teeming with tourists. The passage also mentions that Greece's near-death experience in July, which led to the closure of banks and the collapse of economic activity, turned Syriza into disciples of TINA ("there is no alternative"). The passage concludes that the new bailout deal will only hold if Tsipras can offer hope of better times ahead.

The passage describes the return of Grant Mitchell, a character from the soap opera EastEnders, to the show after a brief absence. The character was last seen in 2006 and was played by Ross Kemp. The return is being made to say goodbye to his mother and be reunited with his brother. The episode will feature emotional scenes of Peggy dying from the disease.

The passage describes the case of Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon, who stalked Alice Ruggles and attacked her last October. Dhillon had become obsessed with Ruggles and stalked her. Ruggles' parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, described the moment when they received a knock on their door from two Northumbria Police officers. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison. The passage also mentions the establishment of the Alice Ruggles Trust and the hope that Ruggles' "vibrant personality" will help to raise awareness of stalking.

The passage discusses the approval of the Â£18bn Hinkley Point nuclear power plant by French firm EDF, which is financing most of the project. However, Business Secretary Greg Clark has said the government will "consider carefully" before backing it. EDF chief executive Vincent de Rivaz has cancelled a trip to Hinkley Point on Friday following Mr Clark's comments. Critics of the plan have warned of environmental damage and potential escalating costs. They are also concerned that the plant is being built by foreign governments. One third of the Â£18bn cost is being provided by Chinese investors. Hours after EDF's board voted to approve the Â£18bn power plant on Thursday, the government launched a further review of the project. The timing seemed calculated to cause maximum impact. EDF executives were taken completely off guard, the post-Brexit run of major investment is abruptly halted and what precious entente cordiale in Anglo-French relations there is left after the EU referendum result seems diminished.

The newly-designed form used to apply for a divorce in England and Wales asks for the name of the person your spouse has committed adultery with. Family lawyers say that, in most cases, involving a third party adds "conflict and complexity". The Ministry of Justice said there was "no obligation" to name people. Lawyer Margaret Heathcote, vice-chairwoman of family law group Resolution, is one of those concerned about the form. "Generally speaking, we don't name the third party. It increases the conflict from day one," she said. "There's no need. But because the box is there, the indication will be to fill it in." The online form has been updated to make the legal process more user-friendly - especially as some complete the process without seeking legal advice. The guidance on the form highlights that it is "not normally necessary" to name the person your spouse committed adultery with. But Georgina Hamblin, director at divorce lawyers, Vardags, said people are "unlikely to read the much smaller print or choose to ignore it". The older version of the form left a space for so-called "co-respondents" to be named where appropriate. "The new form flatly asks for 'the name

The passage discusses the importance of trees for timber production in Britain, particularly in Wales, where conifer forests have been a significant part of the timber industry for decades. However, there has been a growing concern about the environmental impact of commercial forestry, particularly the loss of woodland and the difficulty of transporting timber through rural communities. The Welsh government has proposed a balance between environmental, economic, and social considerations in how forestry is developed.

The passage describes an incident in which a boy was struck in Coatbridge and taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow. The boy was badly injured and is believed to be in serious condition.

The passage describes the presentation of Ushakov medals to veterans of the Arctic Convoys by Defence AttachÃ© Capt Oleg Kornienko. The medals were initially denied by the Foreign Office due to breaking rules on foreign medals. However, the Russian embassy said the convoys allowed Russian soldiers to defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front. The veterans were honored for their service and the Arctic Convoys were a material expression of their wartime alliance. The British Government created the Arctic Star in 2012 to recognize the veterans, but the Foreign Office blocked the move due to its rules. The medals were finally presented by President Vladimir Putin during his visit to London in 2013.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays in getting offenders to start their work and said too many were let off if they did not attend. In one case, an offender had completed just 16 hours in the 17 months since he had been sentenced. The Ministry of Justice said it was acting on the report's recommendations. Anything from 40 to 300 hours of unpaid work - or "community payback" - may be given for offences like shoplifting, theft, drug offences, or criminal damage. Some 70,000 offenders were ordered to do unpaid work such as garden maintenance, decorating or litter-picking in 2014. Inspectors looked at 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders from different probation divisions for their report. The report outlined 15 recommendations for improvement. Some of the problems identified were: Seven years ago the government, then led by Gordon Brown, placed an order for 10,000 orange bibs. They were to be worn by offenders doing unpaid work under a re-branded scheme known as "community payback". It was intended to give the public confidence that community sentences, involving clearing communal paths and gardens,

The paper criticized the comedian for his campaign for economic and political "revolution" to help poorer people, despite his luxurious lifestyle. The comedian, who is known for his vlogs, was asked about his own accommodation by a TV reporter, and he called the reporter "a snide". The star has been condemned as a hypocrite many times before, and he has explained that he believes in change and that he has to change as an individual.

The passage describes the life and career of Dr. James D. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur who turned his efforts to mapping the human genome into a competitive race. He was vilified by the scientific community for his efforts, but his work has undeniably helped speed up the entire process. Dr. Venter also turned his attention to another grand project: the creation of a synthetic life form. The US-based J. Craig Venter Institute has been working on this endeavor for more than a decade. They have now published details of the result, an organism called Synthia, in the prestigious journal Science.

The passage discusses the results of a survey conducted by the England's School Food Trust, which found that four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they had not tried at home. Half of parents questioned said their children had asked for foods they had eaten at school to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while the least popular were aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach. The survey was conducted online between 26 February and 5th March among a panel of parents who had at least one child in school aged 4-17 years old.

The passage describes the career of Morata, a Spanish footballer who joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. He has scored three times for Spain in the Euro 2016 tournament and has scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italia titles. Morata has also played in back-to-back Champions League finals, appearing as a substitute in Real Madrid's 2014 win and scoring in Juventus' 3-1 defeat by Barcelona in 2015. The passage also mentions that Morata came through the ranks at Real Madrid and made his first team debut at 18, scoring 10 goals for the La Liga side.

The passage describes Wilson's career as a professional footballer, including his time at Forest, Celtic, Preston North End, and Notts County. It also mentions that he rejoined Forest in August 2013 after being released in May.

Tesco is looking to dispose of its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, which operates 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona. The deal involves transferring around 4,000 employees to the new business and loaning around Â£80m to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company focused on supermarket and restaurant businesses. If Yucaipa is successful and the business becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake.

The passage describes a man who initially experienced racial abuse but overcame it and is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. It also mentions a special guide on getting into martial arts.

The passage describes the retreat of glaciers in the French Alps over the past 40 years. The glaciers in the Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye, and Grande Rousse Arves massifs, as well as the famous Mont Blanc Massif, have lost significant areas of ice. The retreat is not uniform across the French Alps, with the greatest losses seen in the southern sectors. The northern region includes the biggest French glacier of all, La Mer de Glace, which has lost some 26% of its area over the last 40 years. Efforts to assess and monitor glacier health are ongoing across the Alpine region.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers to date and host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday knowing victory would all but secure their place. Iceland, ranked one place above the Scots at number 20 in the world, are also unbeaten after four wins from four, with the outcome of Friday's contest and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September likely to decide who tops the group. The best six of the eight group runners-up also qualify automatically, Scotland are in pole position to reach next summer's finals in the Netherlands without the need for a play-off.

The passage describes the arrest of Stuart Campbell, a former computer games reviewer, in the west of England. He was arrested following a complaint from a woman in south London who alleged harassment over a two-year period. Campbell was released on bail and accused the media of "innuendo" designed to encourage "speculations". He accused the blogger of being a vocal campaigner for Scottish independence and launching the Wings Over Scotland blog in 2011. Campbell has been bailed, pending further inquiries, to a date in mid-September.

The people for the ethical treatment of animals (PETA) wants the mascot of Skegness to be replaced with a modern animal-friendly version. The group has suggested a fish with the slogan Skegness - A Happy Plaice. The mayor of Skegness said all suggestions were welcome but said he did not think there would be much support for Jolly to be axed. The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned by the Great Northern Railway to encourage visitors to take the train on their seaside breaks to Skegness. The poster featured the slogan "Skegness is so bracing". It was commissioned in 1908 for 12 guineas and has become synonymous with the Lincolnshire resort. However, Dawn Carr, of PETA, said Jolly "evokes images of cruelty to animals". "Fish being tricked into impaling themselves in the mouth, animals being pulled out of the ocean in giant nets where they are so crushed together the pressure pushes their stomachs out through their mouths and their eyes pop out." "This is what the Jolly Fisherman represents," she said. She said PETA's suggestion would give the resort an opportunity to rebrand itself as a progressive holiday destination

The passage describes a rugby match between Scotland and Georgia. Scotland leads 38-11 at halftime, with Stuart Hogg scoring four tries and Greig Laidlaw converting two. Georgia scores two tries in the second half, but Scotland manages to hold onto the ball and score more points. The match ends with Scotland leading 42-11.

The passage describes the match between Widnes Vikings and Castleford Tigers, which ended in a 38-12 loss for the Vikings. The Vikings were led by tries from Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, but were unable to hold on to their lead as Castleford scored three tries in four minutes. The Vikings were also unable to stop Castleford's Solomona, Monaghan, Crooks, Webster, Flynn, McShane, Gale, Jewitt, Milner, Patrick, Moors, McMeeken, Massey, and Replacements Millington, Springer, Tickle, Cook. The Tigers won the match despite losing nine of their previous ten matches.

The passage describes the release of Fawzi al-Odah from the US facility in Cuba after a US review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat". He had been arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, and had challenged America's right to detain him in the US Supreme Court. He was released after the Guantanamo Periodic Review Board determined that continued law of war detention of Mr Odah did not remain necessary to protect against a continuing significant threat to the security of the United States. He now faces at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait. The total number of inmates at the US naval base has dropped to 148, with the release of five Taliban detainees in May when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl, who had been kept by the insurgents in Afghanistan.

The passage describes the events surrounding Anzac Day, a day commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. The service was held at Hyde Park Corner and Westminster Abbey, with the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia being sung. The first time Anzac Day was commemorated in the capital was when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service in 1916, a year after the Anzac landings at Gallipoli. The parade at the Cenotaph featured prayers read by schoolchildren and the national anthems of all three countries. The passage also mentions the eight-month campaign on the Gallipoli peninsula in Turkey, which was one of the bloodiest of the war and an attempt to force the Ottoman empire out of the war.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, will call on pensioners and their friends and families to share their experiences of residential care. The commissioner's review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales will focus on physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. The passage describes the life and career of Dr. James D. Watson, a biologist and entrepreneur who turned his efforts to mapping the human genome into a competitive race. He was vilified by the scientific community for his claims of a level of consistency with other scientists who have won the Nobel Prize in medicine. However, his efforts in the field of human genomics have undeniably helped speed up the entire process. Dr. Watson also turned his attention to another grand project: the creation of a synthetic life form. Scientists at the US-based J Craig Venter Institute have been busily working on the endeavor for more than a decade. They have now published details of the result, an organism called Synthia, in the prestigious journal Science.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in Europe are low quality and too short, and that the Department for Education is reforming apprenticeships to drive up standards. The report also notes that England has a patchwork vocational system with too many young people offered qualifications of little worth, and that the majority of apprenticeships are aimed at older workers. The report calls for apprenticeships to be radically expanded, with up to 300,000 new starts each year. The majority of these should be at level three at least for three years, with some four-year courses at level four - higher than A-levels.

The passage describes the British Paralympic cyclist, Storey, who won a 17th title in Nottwil, Switzerland. She is targeting further Paralympic success at the 2016 Games in Rio de Janeiro. Storey is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals. She has won 11 gold, eight silver and three bronze medals in both cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. She won four golds at the 2012 Games in London and has now won 21 world titles across both sports. The Bulls' financial troubles have been a major factor in their relegation from the Football League. They were reinstated as a Conference Premier club and Hayes & Yeading will stay in Conference South. Hereford United can have no complaints about the Conference's actions. The former Manchester City man, 30, won 61 caps for England after making his senior debut in 2009. Christopher Hogwood, a conductor and musicologist, passed away in Cambridge following an illness. His funeral will be private, and a memorial service will be held at a later date. He worked with many leading orchestras around the world and was considered one of the most influential exponents of the early-music movement. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973 and directed it across six continents for some 30 years. He made more than 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. He studied keyboard at Cambridge University with Rafael Puyana and Mary Potts and later with Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt. He was the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He was also a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University in the US.

The passage notes that a study indicates that following the example of the Hollywood star cuts their risk of dying from breast cancer by more than 60 per cent. The passage also mentions that women who carry a mutated version of BRCA1 or another gene known as BRCA2 face a life-time risk of breast cancer of up to 70 per cent. If diagnosed, they face a severe threat of ovarian tumours. The passage states that the researchers in Canada analysed 676 breast cancer patients who had one of the mutated genes, nearly half (345) underwent oophorectomy after their diagnosis. The couple, Derek Lowe and Tina Lowe, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina. The train was traveling from Charlotte to New York City when the accident occurred. The train was delayed for almost three hours before continuing on its way. The couple were found dead at the scene.

The passage describes the story of Carlos Toro, a former member of the Medellin cartel who worked as an undercover agent for the DEA for 27 years. He was offered US citizenship in exchange for his information, but he declined it due to fear of deportation. Toro is now living in the US illegally and has been facing deportation since 2014. The DEA refused to help him with his citizenship, and he is currently in limbo while trying to get a green card or a passport.

The US body regulating internet addresses is looking to crack down on a Canadian company using the domain name "sucks" to extract exorbitant sums from celebrities such as Kevin Spacey and companies looking to protect their reputations. The passage describes the case of a baby boy who was found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury's bag floating on a village pond 27 years after his body was discovered. The police exhumed the boy's body from his grave in Norfolk last year after the case came up for periodic review. A DNA sample eventually led them to his mother. The woman, who has not been named, was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped after she explained how the baby had been stillborn and that she had concealed the pregnancy from her family and friends. She explained how she had placed her dead baby in the pond in the village of Weasenham St Peter on June 5, 1988, just a few days before it was found by teenagers on a Sunday afternoon outing. The boy's body was exhumed by officers as part of a case review, with DNA samples leading police to the boy's mother. He has now been reburied at Weasenham St Peter Church, Norfolk. The passage describes a case involving a taxi driver who mistakenly believed a passenger was planning to "do a runner" and drove him back to the rank, causing the passenger severe brain injuries. The passenger, Kristopher Hicks, took action to escape and was injured in the process. The case was taken to court, and the driver was found to have unlawfully imprisoned Mr. Hicks, who was entitled to damages. The exact amount of compensation is yet to be determined, but is set to be around 50% of what the family had requested and thought to be "hundreds of thousands of pounds."

The passage describes several tornadoes that occurred in Kansas on Wednesday night, with one tornado reported near Goddard, 15 miles west of Wichita. The passage also mentions other tornado reports from southwestern Kansas, including one near Aetna, 125 miles southwest of Wichita. The passage notes that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly and dangerous, and that tornadoes may have touched down in the small town of Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis. Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight bout on Saturday in New Jersey. Rockhold is seeking his fourth consecutive victory after losing to Vitor Belfort two years ago and has a title shot in his sights. He believes he can dominate Machida and cut him off, slow progress, and be the bull. Machida likes to run around and dance, and Rockhold will use his mixed martial arts skills to take advantage of his weaknesses.

The passage describes a light general aviation aircraft that lands without its landing gear deployed on a runway in Fort Pierce, Florida. The aircraft skids along the runway on its belly and makes a sharp landing with a bump and scratches along the tarmac. The pilot re-engages the engines and takes off back into the air. The aircraft's propellers are damaged in the collision with the runway, and the pilot is able to regain control and land safely. The most common cause of a gear-up landing is human error, and another cause is mechanical fault. The FAA is investigating the incident.

The passage discusses Manchester City's midfielder Yaya Toure, who has been criticized for his performances this season. Manuel Pellegrini, the manager of Manchester City, has admitted that he is disappointed in Toure's level of play and has vowed to back the midfielder until the end of the season. City is facing a difficult season, with just 18 points from the last available 39 games, and will face West Ham without captain Vincent Kompany. Allardyce has warned Aaron Cresswell not to make the same mistake as others by moving to City, and Manchester City wants to sign West Ham's left-back Aaron Cresswell in the summer.

The passage describes the case of Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian Mafia fugitive who was extradited to Italy in 1999 but later lost his battle against extradition and was told he must return to Italy to serve his sentence. The passage notes that Rancadore's case expired last October and his European Arrest Warrant is to be withdrawn. The passage also mentions that Rancadore has lived in Britain for more than 20 years and was given a seven-year sentence by an Italian court in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra. The passage also notes that Rancadore was convicted in absentia in Italy for his role as a "man of honor" and that his conviction remains intact. The Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday features three 7-2 co-favourites: Mr Mole, Irish Racer Special Tiara, and Sprinter Sacre, ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico De Boinville. Mr Mole is McCoy's last ride as a professional jockey, and his book of rides for his final day as a professional jockey will not be finalised until Friday morning. The passage describes the story of Virginia Trimble Ritter, the mother of a girl who was murdered 40 years ago. The girl, Marcia, was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared, and her then-husband advised her against seeing the body and the crime scene photos. Virginia Trimble Ritter finally asked to see the crime scene photos of her daughter's body and now says she wants revenge. The case was Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years. In 1979, police charged a Trimble neighbor with the slaying, but prosecutors dropped the charges about a year later because of lack of evidence. Barrett, who was 15 at the time of the crime, was arrested in 2006 after police matched the DNA on the murdered child's clothing to that of his. The match happened after he was arrested for the 1975 murder of Vanderbilt University student Sarah Vannatta Des Prez. Barrett was found guilty of second-degree murder of Marcia and a Davidson County Criminal Court Jury imposed a sentence of 44 years.

Rory McIlroy believes that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career Grand Slam. He also revealed that his final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 was the most important day of his career. He is looking to claim his first Green Jacket and become just the sixth player to win all four major titles after Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. He is hoping to complete his Grand Slam of Majors with a victory at Augusta later this month. However, he cannot picture going through his career without slipping on at least one coveted Green Jacket.

The week was busy with trending stories, including the appearance of four rainbows in the New York area, Amanda Curtis taking a photo of them, exotic dancers performing in rural China, and the UK channel 4 interviewer asking about Johnny Depp's private life. The passage discusses the impact of alcohol consumption during pregnancy on the health of children born with foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS). According to the data from the Official Health and Social Care Information Centre, 272 children were hospitalised in England due to FAS over the past year. However, experts warn that the actual number of affected children may be much higher. The passage also mentions research by the World Health Organization suggesting that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to exposure to alcohol in the womb.

An axe-wielding robber was arrested after attempting to rob a store. The store owner jumped on the robber and hit him with a baseball bat. The robber was identified as ex-juvenile offender Shaun Andrew McKerry, who was previously known as Boomerang Boy or Homing Pigeon Boy. He was sentenced to six years in jail.

The passage describes the case of four Royal Navy sailors who were charged with raping a young woman at a party at a Canadian barracks. The sailors were given bail conditions that required them to live on a Canadian naval base for the next few years. They were also ordered to surrender their passports and work for the Royal Navy. The sailors were released from custody and driven to their new home on the nearby Stadacona Naval Base.

The passage describes a mother who has a rare skin disorder called Netherton's Syndrome. The mother is shocked when a stranger reports her to the police for child abuse, but it turns out that the skin condition is actually a rare congenital skin disease that causes the skin to appear red and scaly. The mother has to regularly cover her son's skin with creams to prevent it from drying out. The mother is also subjected to taunts from other mothers who accuse her of burning her son. The mother is desperate to find out what is wrong with her son and turns to the internet to learn more about the condition.

The controversial protein world advertisements featuring a bikini-clad model called Renee Somerfield have been removed from the London Underground after receiving more than 50,000 signatures on a Change.org petition calling for their removal. A Florida mother has accused a school of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son because of essential oils he wears to help combat his illness. The passage describes an argument between two Brisbane neighbours over noise levels, resulting in one man's death and the other being charged with manslaughter. An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. after attempting to break into a house at midnight. The passage describes a freelance photographer named Atif Saeed, who captured an image of a hungry lion from just a few feet away. He was in the city's safari park when he spotted the male lion in the distance. Saeed got out of his car and crept up towards the lion, armed only with a camera. He managed to capture a couple of frames before leaving the safety of his car to lie on the ground, but the lion alerted him and he had to retreat quickly. The incident was a close encounter, and Saeed said he would not be able to do it again.

The New York City Police Department has released an image of a tattoo found on the body of a woman who died in Brooklyn last month. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found lying unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. Paramedics were unable to revive her and she was pronounced dead that evening. The tattoo on her right leg reads "Monique" and is believed to be the name of the deceased woman. The investigation is ongoing and anyone with information about the woman is being asked to contact the New York City Police Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

The New Zealand couple built a home on the back of an old flatbed truck. They purchased a 1986 Hino flatbed and undertook a year and a half of labor of love to build a solar-powered two-bedroom, wood and steel home. The result is a cozy, all-wooden home that allows them to live almost self-sufficiently in Nelson, New Zealand. The truck became the foundation of the home, and the couple made do with what they had to build the home. They started with a steel frame and gradually built the home over the course of a year and a half. The home is powered mostly by solar panels, and the couple even plans to build another one like one day.

The passage discusses the impact of sharing iPads in class on early literacy tests. It states that children who share iPads do significantly better in these tests compared to those who do not. The research conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in classes over an academic year scored around 30 points higher than their peers who used the device on their own and non-ipad users. The study suggests that the collaborative learning around the technology made the difference, not just the collaboration in and of itself. The findings have implications for how schools use technology, particularly in earlier grades, to make the technology most effective.

The passage describes a piglet that was born without its back legs and learned to walk on its front legs. It was featured in a heartwarming video on People's Daily Online, where it took unsteady steps and wobbled about with its snout to the ground. The piglet is now known as "Super Pig" and has captured the hearts of thousands. It is not the first animal with two legs instead of four to win plaudits in China, as a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also became a star attraction after learning to walk on its front paws.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone's car during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana. Phillips was hit by the car of Francesco Dracone, who had come in on lap 25 for tires and fuel. The car spun while exiting its pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was taken to the infield care center for treatment where he received stitches for a cut on his leg and was released. The passage describes a husband who battered and shot his wife multiple times while she was dancing. He confessed that he did this because he was jealous of other men looking at her. The wife was killed and her body was found in the garden of their apartment. The husband was later arrested and charged with murder.

The passage describes the personal battle of a journalist and author named Sarah Wilson with mental illness. She experienced anxiety that led her to believe her life was not worth living. The passage also mentions that anxiety is rapidly becoming the new depression, and that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime.

An Oregon woman named Elena Curtin was charged with second-degree assault after she hit her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. She was seven months pregnant at the time and gave birth in January. When she returned home, she found her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend taking heroin in the bathroom. She beat her with a crowbar and the ex-girlfriend refused to leave. The ex-girlfriend was jealous and bitter that the boyfriend was in a relationship with her. The boyfriend struggled with heroin in the past and had a five-year-old child with the ex-girlfriend. They have since reconciled and Curtin is now living with her parents. If she had gone to trial and been convicted, she would have received a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

The passage describes a pit bull named Gemma who is being fed broccoli as part of a trick to make her eat vegetables. Gemma pulls a look of disgust when she chomps on the broccoli and spits it out on the floor. The passage also mentions that Gemma enjoys sleeping and hanging out with her human family.

The HSBC website was directed to a pornographic page after a link on the website was accidentally redirected to the page. The pornographic page was created after the awards were scrapped in 2011 and the organizers allowed it to be registered on the HSBC website. The bank removed the link from its main website after realizing its mistake.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus provided instructions to firefighters during a 911 call when his family's home caught fire on Sunday morning. He and his nine-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom after the fire broke out on the first floor of their home in Clinton. Marcus called 911 shortly before 7 am after he smelled smoke and told the dispatcher that his older brother, mother, and step-father were also in the home. He told the dispatcher that his sister was screaming, "We're going to die," during the call. The firefighters were able to rescue Marcus and his sister by going through the home and breaking a window. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.

The passage describes the stunning sight of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically Jervis Bay in New South Wales. The algae was captured by photographer Andy Hutchinson, who described it as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton omitting light. A similar display was shown in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, where an oceanography expert told Daily Mail Australia there was no need to be concerned about the algae. Iain Suthers, of the University of New South Wales, explains that the algae blossoms in the spring and autumn and is caused by natural causes.

Breast cancer patients may be spared chemotherapy due to new tests that pinpoint genetic markers in the tumour and determine its aggressiveness. After surgery, the cancer cells are sent to a lab where they are screened, and women can be told within days whether they have a high or low risk of the disease returning. For some women, the test can accurately tell if the risk is as low as five per cent, which is as good as if not better than the odds for those who have chemotherapy. The majority of women who have breast cancer are routinely given the gruelling drug treatment following removal of the tumour to prevent recurrence. Although the medication kills off cancer cells, the side effects, including complete hair loss, nausea, sickness, weight gain or loss, and extreme fatigue, can be difficult to live with. For some women, the prospect of chemotherapy is more daunting than the surgery itself. However, experts have long-believed that the risk of cancer recurrence for certain women is a lot less than for others, and that for some, chemotherapy may not be necessary. If the newest of the tests, called endopredict, shows a low score, patients can opt not to have chemotherapy. Most of the tests are available only privately and cost about

The Royal Navy has airlifted more than 25 pregnant women from ships over the past nine years. One ship, HMS Ocean, had five pregnant sailors removed in emergency medevac operations during this period. At least one woman was airlifted from HMS Illustrious, which was previously known as HMS Lusty. The Ministry of Defence has confirmed that there is a strict "no touching" rule in place at sea, suggesting that the women were not pregnant when they boarded the ships or during leave. The data comes nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following claims she had a sexual relationship with a member of her crew. The Ministry of Defence would not confirm what these reasons were or what action she would face. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990 and in 2014 around 9% of personnel were female. Three women made history by becoming the first female submariners to serve in the Royal Navy in May 2014. Nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after finding out they were pregnant. Ninety-nine servicewomen on operations were flown back

Tokyo has been alarmed by the discovery of a drone carrying traces of radioactive material on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House. The drone was found on the same day that a Japanese court approved a government plan to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant in Kagoshima Prefecture, more than four years after the Fukuhi Daiichi nuclear disaster. The discovery has raised concerns about terrorism involving drones, and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's push to restart the reactors is unpopular among many Japanese, who view nuclear energy as too dangerous. A staff member spotted the drone on Wednesday morning, and dozens of police investigators were dispatched to the roof to investigate the origin of the drone, which had four propellers and was 50 centimeters wide. The drone was equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing small traces of radioactive material believed to be cesium, a common byproduct of nuclear reactors. The amount inside is not immediately harmful to humans. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Sugita said the discovery is raising concerns about terrorism, and the government will do all that it can to prevent terrorism. Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports to prevent problems with aircraft, but there are no flight restrictions

The passage describes a man named Lu Xincai who takes his 84-year-old mother with him to work on the back of his motorbike every day. He ties a sash around both of their waists to make sure she does not fall off. He also ensures that she has her own room by the bank where he works. The passage also mentions that Lu Xincai's mother suffers from Alzheimer's and used to get lost when left alone.

The study concludes that more Americans are drinking heavily, with a 17.2% increase in heavy drinking between 2005 and 2012. The increase is largely due to rising rates among women, with social norms changing. The study also found that binge drinking rates among women increased more than seven times the rate among men. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level.

Doctors are performing caesarean sections too frequently, putting women and their babies at risk of infections and even death. The WHO warns that the procedure should only be carried out when "medically necessary" and that it can lead to significant complications, disability, or death. The WHO's statement contradicts current NHS guidelines, which say the procedure should be offered to women even when there is no medical justification. Women are also advised to have planned caesareans if they have had a previous complicated birth, are over 40, or have a medical condition such as asthma, diabetes, or depression. However, the WHO says that doctors are performing them too often and underestimating the risks.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, Massachusetts, was arrested after allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living inside for at least a week and selling items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. Michelle Filkins was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property after being arrested on April 17, 2019. The lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke was found at a police station on the NSW-Victoria border. The phone was unlocked and used to post selfies and photos on Bella's Facebook page. The police officers on duty realised the phone was unlocked and used it to post selfies and photos of the phone in various locations around the police station on Bella's Facebook page. Bella lost her phone at a friend's birthday party the night before and dialled her number as soon as she realised. The phone belonged to Bella Crooke who lost it at a friend's birthday party on Saturday night. The police officers on duty realised the phone was unlocked and used it to post selfies and photos on Bella's Facebook page, including this photo of the phone in a holding cell. While waiting for Bella to collect her phone, police had used the time to post a picture of the handset in a holding cell and to reassure the owner that it was in safe hands. The phone was still there, ready to be released early for good behavior. Bella said she did not even have to give her name when she eventually reclaimed her phone. A large-scale study has found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be fat as toddlers. The researchers said that antibiotics are used to make farm animals put on weight, and this may also be fattening our children. The study compared the weight and height of more than 12,000 healthy two year old with records on antibiotic prescription. By two years-old, one in five boys and one in ten girls was overweight or obese. And children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight. The study didn't prove that antibiotics were causing weight gain, but if they do, it may be because they kill of bugs in the gut that would normally feed on some of the food eaten. This frees up more food for the body.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, causing a commotion among the tourists. The incident was captured on camera by a tourist, who recorded the moment. The guard quickly scrambled to his feet and turned to march past the crowd, but his embarrassment was evident as he peered at the crowd from under his bearskin. The passage discusses the reimagining of the miniseries "Roots" for new audiences. The original series, which aired in 1977, had a massive audience of over 100 million viewers.
